response.answer_text: eh kind of wordy but here ya go Do humans have free will? Few questions cut to the core of human experience quicker then this one. It's easy to see why. With free will we are in control of our lives and morally responsible for our actions, without free will we are reduced to mere robots following out the programming given to us. The implications of free will are staggering and yet the human race has failed to reach a consensus on a question that is absolutely essential to our existence. Do we have free will? Our everyday experience tells us yes, but the logic of science tells us no. And so we reach a stalemate. Determinists, Compatibilists, Libertarianists, and many other "ists" argue amongst themselves throwing out concepts and getting entrenched in their viewpoints with no progress ever being made. Debated for thousands of years, no one ever thought to question to the question. Humans don't have free will. Free Will has us. Before you let this ridiculous and absurd sounding statement fool you, lets first take a look at what exactly Free Will is and isn't. The commonly held definition of Free Will is "the ability to freely choose between different possible courses of action." This definition seems to be appropriate and in line with our everyday experience at first glance. If we can choose between different courses of action (and it feels like we can) than we have free will, if we can't choose between different courses of action then we don't. Seems straightforward right? Either we have free will or we don't. Our everyday experience supports it (Libertarians, Compatiblilists), and the physical laws of the universe refutes it (Determinism). This is where 99% of the people get tripped up and stop. They take a side, either yes or no, and they make their stand, not moving an inch. That is unfortunate for them however, because our journey to the truth of Free Will is just beginning. "The ability to freely choose between different courses of action". Regardless of if you believe in this definition of free will or not, this is a good place to start our inquiry. You will see soon that this definition crumbles under scrutiny and will soon be irrelevant. So withhold your concerns for a moment and keep an open mind, we are headed to the uncharted waters of discovery. "The ability to freely choose between different courses of action". Lets start by analyzing the assumptions and implications of this statement. "The ability to freely choose" implies a lack of necessity and restriction on the choices we make. For example, lets say I'm deciding between an apple and a banana for a snack and I choose to eat an apple. Eating an apple vs eating an banana are two possible courses of action that I freely chose between even though I ultimately chose to eat an apple. However here a question arises: WHY did I eat an apple? I could've ate a banana, but I chose to eat to an apple. Why? Why do we make the choices we make? This is a very powerful question that can destroy a lot of the false assumptions that exist around free will. Why do we make the choices we make? There must be a reason....right? Lets examine the possible answers to the "Why" question and see what it means for free will: Why did I choose to eat an apple instead of a banana? I chose to eat an apple because it was more desirableI chose to eat an apple for no reasonThose are the only two options. That's it. And when you look at it, option 1 is the only acceptable justification for free will. Think about it. If I ate an apple for no reason at all, how is that choice of my own Free Will? If you don't even know the reason for your actions, then you are acting randomly, at the whims of fate. In order to have a free choice, you must have a reason for making that choice. Indeed, reasons must form the basis for choices because the very act of choosing requires comparison and evaluation of the reasons for choosing the different options. If there is no reason for choosing, there can be no meaningful choice. So there must be a reason for our choices, otherwise we would not be making any choices at all. What is the reason for our choices? The choice that we will choose will always be the most desirable choice at the time according to the given information. Period. Even if the choice seems to be undesirable, (self-starvation or torture) it is always the most desirable choice at the time it was chosen. If this is not self evident to you please contemplate why you make the choices you do further, but we must move on to our next big question: "Do we choose our desires?" "Do we choose our desires?" If you accept the premises that no choice can be made without a reason, and the reason we base our choices on is desirability, the next question that logically follows is "do we choose our desires?". This is a very important question. If we choose our desires then we can have Free Will, as the the value ranking system (desirability) governing our choices would be under our control. If we can not choose our desires, then human Free Will is impossible, as we would be totally controlled by our desires, not unlike a puppet on a string. This is an unpleasant notion to be sure, so lets start our inquiry by assuming that we can choose our desires. If we can choose our desires, then we need a reason for choosing our desires. Without a reason for choosing, no meaningful choice can be made. Yet here we run into a paradox: how can we choose our desires when our desires are the very mechanism we use for making choices in the first place?! It is impossible, we can't: in order to make a choice we need desires, so it is impossible for us to have chosen all of our desires. We were born initially with desires that we didn't choose, and these desires determined the choices that will determine the course of our entire lives. Regardless of whether we are free to fulfill our desires or not, the critical point is this: we are not in control of the desires we have. "If we are not in control of our desires, what is?" This is the next critical question. If we do not choose our desires, where do they come from? There are only 2 possible factors that can determine our desires: genetics + environment. The environment that you were born into, along with the genes that you were born with determine your desires, decisions, and the course of your entire life. And you have no control over either. If you disagree, think about this question: "Did you choose the environment and genes that you were born with? No, obviously you did not. This truth is undeniable. Environment and genetics forms the totality of human decision making and it is out of the scope of our control. Lets examine and see how environment and genetics functions: Environment (Input) v Genetics (Program) v Decision (Output) Much like a computer program, human beings are totally controlled by their programming. The genetics you are born with is your initial program and the environment is the input that that is ran through the program to create an output, or decision. The human persona which takes credit for decisions can be compared to a figurehead president who is completely at the mercy of his government even though it outwardly seems like he is in control. While you may still think that "you" chose to wake up this morning, the fact is that it was your genetics and environment that led you to make that decision. And you can not have chose your genetics because it is your very genetics that chooses! No matter how you look at it, the conclusion is inescapable. Lets recap the ground we've covered so far so we are on the same page moving forward. If you disagree with any of the premises, do not move on until you are satisfied. MeanFree Will is the ability to freely choose between different courses of actionThere must be a reason (value ranking system) for a choice to be meaningful.The choice that is chosen is always the most desirable (highest value)Humans can not choose the desires (value ranking system) that determine their choicesSince humans do not choose the program (value ranking system) that determines their choices, they do not have free will.Conclusion: Humans do not have free will. A compatibilist would argue that humans have free will as long as they are free to fulfill their desires, but considering the fact that all of our desires are given to us by factors completely out of our control (genetics and environment), this argument seems to be a cop out of the finest order. Is a puppet free if he loves his strings? In my opinion no he is not, but its up to you to decide for yourself. Freedom, it seems, has everything to do with a lack of necessity and constraint, and all independent decision-making entities (programs, humans) require necessity and constraint in the form of a value ranking system in order to make meaningful choices. If an independent decision-making entity was completely free, it would have no framework with which to make any choices at all, no way of comparing and evaluating different options, and no way to even comprehend its own existence. Freedom is an ideal that is impossible to live up to, yet humans have always had the strange conviction that freedom is ours, despite countless evidence to the contrary. Is this conviction wrong? Is determinism right after all? What determines the program (genetics) and input (environment) that determines all of our choices? Tune in next time to find out! Its not like you have a choice ;) *hint who has free will? ;)

It is possible, but hard to see how. When I say that it's "hard to see how," that's not the same as to say that it's implausible. It is very possible, but first we would need to take out a powerful and very persistent philosophical argument: If the universe is deterministic, then we obviously don't have free will, because we can't have chosen otherwise.If the universe is not deterministic, then it is random. If our decisions are random, they're not freely willed.Determinism and randomness exhaust the possibilities.Therefore, we cannot possibly have free will.This is a powerful argument, and many knowledgeable and credible people do accept it or at least consider it a threat. It seems to indicate that self-determination would require an infinite regress of self-determined actions, each of which is caused by the one prior; this possibility seems ridiculous to many people, and seems to make free will incoherent whether they believe in a "soul" or not. So where's the (potential) problem with the argument? Depends on your position. There are those who dispute the first premise. They're called "compatibilists", and they believe that determinism and free will are perfectly compatible. They would say that it's not really important that your decisions are determined; they're still yours. You choose them, based on the unique confluence of factors that make up who you are. "You could have done otherwise than you have done," most compatibilists say, "if you had wanted otherwise." This is a popular position, and until recently it was the mainstream position among analytic philosophers. But there are good reasons not to believe in determinism. Certain interpretations (including the orthodox Copenhagen interpretation) of quantum mechanics are indeterministic, and that's just the tip of the iceberg. Massimo Pigliucci wrote a guide about skepticism regarding determinism: http://rationallyspeaking.blogspot.com/2011/12/handy-dandy-guide-for-skeptic-of.html (also worth reading on the topic: http://rationallyspeaking.blogspot.com/2012/01/jerry-coyne-on-free-will.html) Some have even argued that taking physics seriously would reduce the importance of concepts such as causation which are often invoked to show the purported incredibility of free will. But half of the battle in arguing about a complex question, like that of free will, is coming to a fruitful definition of the concept at hand. I don't think there's any reason to rule compatibilistic definitions out before giving them a fair shot. In some ways, they may capture more of what is important about our "common-sense" concepts of free will than libertarian definitions, and they may bear more relevance to ethics and the law. Compatibilists would likely look to psychology to determine if a decision is free. Was it make under duress or temptation? Was the person's will weak? How does he or she justify or excuse his or her actions? These are crucial questions for anyone interested in the links between human action and moral responsibility. There are those who dispute the second premise. They believe that if a decision is created from a confluence of indeterministic and deterministic factors, it is possible for it to be a rational choice of the agent in such a way that the agent could have done otherwise. One question that needs to be addressed is if quantum mechanics is necessary to understand decisions. There are many ways this has been proposed to occur - some ridiculous, some less so. There are dozens of decision models that show different ways that this kind of free will could work. Proponents of these models say that they make it possible to make an undetermined decision that's still a "me" decision. But some people say that these models still don't really guarantee us real free will. One could argue, for example, that if we could build a probability distribution of our decisions, then we don't really have free will; instead, decisions are just a matter of random "luck". I'm among those who believes that such actions would not be free in a libertarian sense. There are those who dispute the third premise. Do randomness and determinism really exhaust the possibilities? It certainly seems like a terrible lack of imagination to assume so. A third way between determinism and randomness could, for example, result from strongly emergent properties. Such accounts are popular among what are called "agent-causal" libertarians. Dispositional accounts of causation are increasingly popular in philosophy of science, and there are powerful arguments, raised by people like (current foremost proponents of dispositionalism) Stephen Mumford and Rani Lill Anjum, that dispositionalists ought to be libertarians about free will. It has been noted (for example, by L. Buchak in "Free Acts and Chance") that the obvious failure in the argument at the top of this answer is that strictly speaking, determinism and randomness are not the only options. We can easily imagine the possibility that, if one were to roll back time and setting it going again, our choices of options would not converge to a particular probability distribution. This wouldn't guarantee free will, but it would be a first step. The notion of self-generation, often held to be key to libertarian free will, is sometimes argued to be incoherent. But I think there is good reason to believe these arguments often contain flawed assumptions. There are probably other avenues one can take, but I lack the creativity to think of them. (For the record, John Conway and Simon Kochen seem to believe that non-deterministic, non-random events are necessary based on their Free Will Theorem in quantum mechanics, but there are deterministic ways around their argument. This is frequently brought up in discussions on free will, but despite the name it is hardly a coup for free will proponents.) Crucially, for someone to act freely does not mean that their every action must be free. If someone, frightened by a loud noise, instinctively drops a delicate tray, we may be less inclined to assign responsibility for its shattering because the action was unconscious. But if that person, through a series of free actions, had built his or her mental capabilities so as not to be frightened, he or she may not have dropped the tray. This is a silly example, but its lesson can be carried to more complex ones. And there are those who dispute the means of argument itself. On a more fundamental level, one could argue that scientific theories are only empirically adequate models about reality, and don't convey metaphysical truths. Others might argue that science takes causality as being axiomatic; they say that, for example, even if there were free decisions, scientists would try to explain them deterministically. Philosophers like Colin McGinn and Thomas Nagel believe free will exists, but we may never discover how it works. These people may say that there is still plenty of room for free will. It has been argued rather extensively that the entire problem is just a language game with no resolution. But these arguments don't really give us much to work with. It's more interesting to argue under the assumption that the theories accepted by scientists are true; otherwise, there's not much to say about the question at all. But we must keep in mind that what we know about physics is like a drop in the ocean. More than 100 years ago, few trained physicists would have taken seriously the possibility of indeterminism at all. There's also the concern that neuroscientific experiments, like those performed by Daniel Wegner and Benjamin Libet, have "disproven" free will. This conclusion is entirely beyond the rather meager evidence for it, and the methodologies and interpretations of such experiments have been heavily criticized. As they say, extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence - and considering the weight on introspection on the side of free will (at least in its compatibilistic form), claiming it doesn't exist is rather extraordinary. In short, we don't really know whether free will does or does not exist. It's premature to go either way. I agree with Scott Aaronson when he says: "But when it comes to the more ethereal questions — the nature of consciousness and free will, [...] etc. — I don’t have any beliefs whatsoever. I’m not even unsure about these questions, in the same Bayesian sense that I’m unsure about next week’s Dow Jones average (or for that matter, this week’s Dow Jones average). All I have regarding the metaphysical questions is a long list of arguments and counterarguments — together with a vague hope that someone, someday, will manage to clarify what the questions even mean." To borrow from Pigliucci again - doubting free will really just serves the same purpose as doubting the existence of the external world. It's useful in that it's humbling, but in the end, there's no reason to do so, and we will (and should) keep assuming free will and assigning moral responsibility anyway. We don't even know what consciousness is. How can we know whether we have free will?

No.What is real is the illusion of free will. This illusion is very complete, very compelling and for all intents and purposes every bit as good as the real thing. We are, for want of a better description, engines that make decisions. So it's not surprising we take responsibility for those decisions. This ownership over our own actions creates the illusion of free will. And very satisfying it is too. But all our choices, deeds and actions are the result of some prior causes: Memories, genetic-predispositions, character defects, accidents, lusts, goals - momentary neurochemical flickerings or just random quantum interactions.  In other words, just atoms doing physics.  No will. No freedom. And all those causes, they too had had prior causes.  If we were an omniscient observer staring into a person, we could watch every one of these golden strands of causality and trace them back in time to before the birth of the person. Alas, we have no such powers. The mind/brain is a black box to us. It's workings obscured. And so we have to satisfy ourselves that the origin of an action was somewhere within that grey meat-computer.  And having done that, we can assign blame.  But pity the poor omniscient observer. He can see the cause of everything, and so is obliged to see every action as blameless and inevitable. EDIT. It's probably worthwhile explaining why free will is impossible.  A lot of people assume this is an argument based on determinism, or brain function or something else. It's simpler than that. In this universe, and pretty much every universe we can imagine, there are only two possible types of event. Class 1) Caused events  - things that happen because earlier things happened.Class 2) Uncaused events - thing that happened without any prior cause. For this argument we can consider thoughts and decisions to be events like anything else.  Including the choice of Cheese or Tuna sandwich.   A class 1 decision is the product of what happened before. A logical process, an accumulation of preferences, a reaction to some event.   There is no freedom in such a decision. It's outcome was forced by what went before. (that's what class 1 is) - Using health conscious input factors we logically chose tuna.  That's a rational and willed decision. But it's not free.  A class 2 decision is unlinked to prior circumstances. As such it must be spontaneous. It must materialise without context or reason.  Quantum phenomena are a good example of this. But we could imagine some mental die-roll which allows us to pick at random and get cheese.  Again there is no possibility of freedom here. Because we can't control or influence such events. Class 2 events must be random. Because it was random, it was not willed. There are no other classes of event. Not in this universe. Not in any universe we can imagine.

Does free will exist? Answer: No! I think we can all agree that it feels like we have free will. But many of our feelings are actually illusions. I see a red apple on the table, I pick it up, I sniff it, and then I drop it on the floor. But there is nothing inherently red in the skin of the apple: it is merely reflecting light of a particular wavelength. My brain detects this and converts it into my perception of red. But if my perception of red had been swapped at birth with my perception of, say, blue, I would never have known the difference. Similarly, I did not touch the apple, I only detected its electrical charge. The apple neither possesses an inherent odor nor makes an inherent noise as it strikes the ground. These are all constructs of my brain, designed by evolution over millions of years to let me know that something is there, but I might never know the absolute true nature of what it is. My point is that when something feels real, it might well not be real. Thus, the fact that free will feels real cannot be relied upon as proof that it is real. We must look deeper. If you search a bit on the Internet, you can find evidence of one or more studies that reveal that "our decisions are made seconds before we become aware of them." So, it would appear that at least much of the time, it's the subconscious mind that makes our decisions for us. This does not bode well for advocates of free will, for surely we would make decisions wholly with our conscious mind. It's interesting that our subconscious mind informs the conscious mind of a decision in such a way so that the conscious mind incorrectly assumes that it made the decision — all on its own. Brain-scan studies say otherwise. It's often said that "everything happens for a reason." Although most of the folks that say this have something else in mind altogether, the true reason is actually "cause and effect". Nothing happens on its own. Of course, what I'm talking about is determinism. But, given that determinism is true, free will can be no more that one of many illusion. As taken from the Internet, determinism is "the doctrine that all events, including human action, are ultimately determined by causes external to the will. Some philosophers have taken determinism to imply that individual human beings have no free will and cannot be held morally responsible for their actions." Logically, it should be enough to simply state that nothing could possibly happen without at least one cause. This should be self-evident. I find it interesting that our intuition tells us that this must be true although many often invoke a god as the cause and yet most adhere to the free will philosophy. Again, this is a key element of religion. Of course, we all know that many religious individuals use the statement, "nothing just happens", to attempt to convince others that the universe itself must have had an architect; ergo, it must have been a god. But they fail to grasp that this must also apply to any god: who was/is god's architect? They also miss the fact that even if this did prove that a god created the universe then it would in no way prove that it's the god that they follow nor that the god took an active interest in his/her/its handiwork following the event. But still, the fact that science can not explain the cause of the birth of our universe is persuasive to a great number of unscientifically minded individuals. It also makes having free will easier to believe, for if the universe had no cause why not other things? To a scientist, the response to the question of how the universe began can often be satisfactorily answered by simply stating "we don't know yet, and we may never know." But of course, this is not going to satisfy very many laymen. To compound the problem, some scientists claim that the universe began with nothing. But they also say that it began as a singularity which is something. So where did the singularity come from? I don't know. Personally, I do not believe that the universe sprang from absolutely nothing. There must have been some energy in some form. Somehow, this energy gave rise to the singularity from which the universe erupted. Scientists often refer to this as a quantum fluctuation, but to us non-cosmologists it's difficult to understand. I also subscribe to the theory that the total energy in the universe is zero. How could it not be?, Or at least, very near zero, since the birth of the universe must have been seeded with a bit of energy. So, for me, I just accept the fact that something must have always existed but I will likely never understand exactly how the universe actually began. This, of course, means that the universe itself had a cause. But this opens up a whole new can of worms: Is the multi-verse —assuming there is one, and I think there is— deterministic as well? I should think that it would have to be. That's not going to sit well with very many folks at all. Oh, well!

I started getting doubts about free will after my wife died from an astrocytoma brain tumour. I took up reading about neuroscience. I read a book by Professor Eric Kandel. Memory, From Mind to Molecules. Second Edition, Larry R. Squire and Eric R. Kandel. Roberts & Company, 2009. A Nobel prize winner. I got information from some huge encyclopedic books. Bibliography later. What he wrote made sense to me. He showed that memory takes place in the synapses around neurons, by a process of training. Your brain contains a huge assembly of these interconnected neurons. By training is meant that if a path through the neurons is traversed frequently it becomes more easily traversed again. On the other hand if a pathway through the neurons is infrequently traversed the strength of the pathway is weakened. A neuron will emit an action potential when sufficient interactions from other neurons takes place in its synapses. The action potential is a pulse of electrical activity that propagates the length of the axon of the neuron and affects the synapses of the neurons that it is connected to. Hence the activity in the biological brain is a huge process of interactions of the action potential pulses around pathways in the brain. It follows that what you experience as a thought is actually the activity along pathways through the neurons in your brain that these interactions take place along. Of course I am skipping some of the more intricate details for the sake of describing the main points without undue waste of time. Read Eric Kandel for the details down to molecular level. The essential ingredients of intelligence are memory and a decision process. Without memory you wouldn't know what is going on and the decision process enables you to make a response to what ever is going on. The neuron has a memory in the synapses and a decision process due to the threshold effect that occurs when an action potential is generated. Hence, the mechanism of the neuron is the mechanism that gives your brain and hence you, intelligence, as well as the ability to think. Your brain is a biological pulse logic system compared with our computers that are silicon based Boolean logic systems. Can you see what is going on here? Your memory and hence your intelligence is produced entirely through the training that takes place during your life. There is no little voice in your head working things out for you, the whole process has been done by training in the neurons of your brain during the course of your life. Consider a newborn baby. The baby is born with instincts to cry if wet, hungry or left alone. The baby has no ability to make a decision, it moves its arms and legs in a somewhat random manner until it eventually finds out through a process of trial and error how to move its arms and legs in a useful manner. As the baby gets older and is sufficiently trained it can of course make decisions but the decisions are entirely based on the training that the baby has received. We as adults have gone to Uni or training school to expand our ability and increase our training to control our environment and participate in it. Unfortunately there is no doubt that we are androids, biological robots with feelings. There is no free will. Consider your digestive system. It has its own neuron based brain that controls the digestive process. Then there are the endocrine glands that do their control through chemicals that they monitor and regulate in the blood stream. For example the sugar level in your blood is controlled to enable your brain to function properly. If you eat too much sugar the process stops working because the gland that controls it only has a limited range of control. Our entire guts are automated by separate parts of neuron based brain or special glands. All you do is get on with your life, whilst your body runs on automation. Having been an octogenarian for some years I can report to you that sex is controlled by a chemical in your blood stream. Up to puberty, about ten years old, I had no interest in sex. After the testosterone was unleashed into the blood stream at puberty, sex became active. Now at my age in my eighties the testosterone has diminished considerably and sex is no longer active. That is, I have a low libido. This is called an andropause, whilst the ladies have a menopause when they run out of eggs. It is all about, well a bit about, sex until you hit the andropause, after which it is all about staying alive without undue discomfort. Biologically, you are no longer useful. Consider the male lion. The lionesses catch the prey, whist he can keep them safe and mate with them, after which they leave him on his own in the Savannah to die of hunger so that they can look for a younger male. No free will applies to all creatures from ants to zebras. Instead you as human can write a book. There is more essential detail to this that I haven’t told you about here but that you can read about in my book. Look out for the revised version of my book: A Theory of Nothing. How is the finite reality created from the infinite? By D. N. Warren-Smith, MSc. Archway Publishers. Should be available in December, 2018. There is a lot more to life that you probably haven’t realised! The corollary for young people is: start learning as quickly as possible, even before you go to school or preschool and perhaps develop a skill. This will give you a much better chance to compete and subsist in this competitive world of biological robots with feelings.

Partially, but it depends on how you define “free will”. It is possible to define free will such that it becomes logically impossible, and it is also possible to define it so that it is obviously real. It turns out, therefore, that answering the question is quite trivial, but defining the term is where the real battle occurs in this argument. As such, I offer a deep dive into the definition, to determine which definition is most intended and sound. Free-will opponents like to define “free will” as the ability to act differently if we were to wind back the clock. They claim this definition is not a straw man because it is uncontroversial, yet I do not see any proponent of free will assert such a definition and no proponent of free will that asserts this definition is provided. They go on to claim that according to this definition, there must be no free will because your action was determined by unseen forces acting prior to conscious awareness, desires and motives, beliefs and presuppositions, that exist outside of consciousness that are in the driver’s seat and that consciousness is merely an observer of the process but not a participant. There are several hidden assumptions behind this meaning, however, that make it invalid and not useful: It implies all or nothing. That is, it implies you must either have total control or none at all, it does not leave room for free will acting only on a case by case basis or acting partially. The proof that is offered implies this bifurcation, an experiment run under very simplistic conditions shows autonomic functions preempting conscious decisions, and it is inexplicably assumed that these results may be extrapolated to define how decisions are made in much more complex circumstances. As such, it sets an artificially low bar for successful assertion, all that one needs to do in order to argue no free will is to demonstrate that desire is in some manner influencing all action, a rather trivial observation. We all know of many cases where our response is all but autonomic, such as when we jump at a fright, etc. It is not the simplistic, routine, highly conditioned cases where we would expect to find free will acting, but rather the most complex cases where extreme deliberation of far reaching consequences is required. To establish that free will exists, one is not required to establish that it always exists, establishing its presence only in some cases is sufficient to prove it not non-existent. One way of stating this case that illustrates the point is to say, we may have freedom to act in accordance with our desires, but if you say you can have whatever color car you want so long as it is green, effectively saying we have freedom but extremely limited choices, therefore you have no freedom at all. This argument would be like saying you can go in any direction, so long as it is in three dimensional space, in other words, since we are limited to desiring what we desire, but since desiring what we desire is the only kind of desire, it is not a real limitation. It is saying, you can do what you want, so long as it is what you want. As I said, not a real limitation.It implies randomness is the only true hallmark of free will. All preferences are reasoned by some desire, without desire there would be no reason for a preference of direction therefore any direction taken without desire would be by definition random. As proof of this, it was a significant discovery when quantum mechanics showed that there are elements of matter, on the quantum level, whose behavior is indeterminate, or random. This was taken as highly influential to the philosophy of determinism, the antithesis of libertarian free will. The problem with randomness being the only true hallmark of free will is that randomness has no value to us, and value underpins the entire argument, that is, we only argue about free will because we consider free will to be of some value. If we arbitrarily define free will to be “acting randomly” then this form of free will would cease to become valuable to anybody. The fact that the form of free will advocated by proponents is considered valuable, forces the definition of “free will” to be something other than “acting randomly.” Even if you could establish that “acting randomly” is the correct definition of free will, and then you established most convincingly that human are not capable of acting randomly, what have you really accomplished? You have established that humans are not capable of something they never asked for or wanted in the first place. This discovery would hold about the same significance as the discovery that humans are not capable of destroying the universe. Since we assume the argument over free will does not lack significance, we should not then define the term in such a way that the inevitable conclusion of the argument is a complete extraction of all significance. This type of straw man fallacy could be compared to children suddenly claiming to not care about winning or losing when they lose in sports, something I have personally seen my children do. Rather than owning up to the loss, they prefer to re-define the loss so that it lacks significance.It does not allow for changes in stimulus, training, reflection, or consideration to occur when the clock is wound back. Why not wind the clock back to 10 years before the event, subjecting me to possibly different experiences over the 10 year period and leading to a different outcome? What is conscious control, if not a change in outcome based on a change in conscious evaluation, when new information is revealed, new insights discovered, etc. If I want a reliable car, I choose based on information available at the time, when new information becomes available, if I still have not made the commitment, I have the power to revise my decision based on the new information. In other words, I am not locked into a decision, but the decision can be altered when new information is made available. Is that not conscious control, when we can freely change our mind when new information is considered?It is not a definition that is asserted by proponents of free will, therefore it is a straw man. If you want to arbitrarily define “free will” in such a manner that it is trivial to take it down, this does not accomplish anything of value and does not make forward progress in the world of philosophy.I will admit, proponents of free will have done a poor job of articulating a definition of this term, leaving the term wide open to opponent definition co-opting. I am a proponent of free will, and while I am no authority on the term, I have thought long and hard about the term and where it is of value to society, therefore I offer the following definition that I would be happy to defend: “The ability, in important cases, to consciously choose one's path to a desired outcome in a manner that considers factors whose awareness is only made possible by human intelligence, consciousness, sentience, and belief in principles.” This definition recognizes the strong role of desire to determine the end result that is envisioned, but leaves, in important cases, the path to that end result up to consciousness. Certainly decisions that require a refined and highly sophisticated understanding of the world would require conscious deliberation, but I propose that when the end result for many paths is the same, we have evolved to leave those particular decisions up to the consciousness. This is not to say that there are no sub-conscious factors influencing the decision, such as strongly held biases, memories of trauma or pain, but these factors act as team members of a consensus, and the arbiter of those voices is the consciousness. This definition stills allows one to justifiably hold a criminal responsible for their crimes. In the case of most crimes, there are many complicated factors that must be considered in order to perpetrate the crime, and the fact that the good will for society was not considered valuable enough to be influential in the decision to commit a crime, is what is offensive to society. In the case of a criminal, the harmony and good will of society was either actively ignored, or considered but rejected as of no worth. In either case, you have a free agent that is by example making the argument that society is of little value, and is not worthy of protection and care. This definition also allows for desire to be in full control of the goal, while giving up control to the consciousness only to the method of accomplishing the goal. It retains the “why” while only giving up the “how.” It allows for autonomic responses while making room for consciousness to play a roll in sophisticated decision making. And it accommodates morals, because while no one could be faulted for wanting what they want, they can be faulted for their chosen path, which must be carefully attenuated to not only reach the goal of desire, but also to fall within a plethora of other constraints and complicated, strategic and moral objectives. Finally, this definition retains value in the form of free will it describes. While we may not have control of our root desires, it is valuable that we have control of the path we choose to accomplish those desires. We can choose the path of greater good, over a shortest path characterized by selfishness and harm. We can choose to create a world where we all achieve our desires together in harmony, rather than a world where we must kill and destroy in order to survive. Finally, we can take credit when we choose good over evil, when we choose hard work and accomplishment over laziness and ineptitude, when we choose kindness and gentleness as oppose to hatred and violence. There is certainly, however, merit in the observation that we often attribute far too much responsibility to people’s behavior than is justified. We are products of a vast indoctrination program, from our genetics to our upbringing, the vast majority of which is not controlled by us. We are trained and condition from birth with certain values, and when some of those values are missing and this absence causes anti-social behavior, we are right to pin some of the blame on bad parenting, or even a long multi-generational history of bad parenting. But this does not require that we can not play a role in our own conditioning. There are countless examples of those that survived traumatic circumstances growing up but went on to choose a different path. At a certain age, we achieve the ability to affect our own conditioning, we become aware that exposure to inputs can have a positive or negative effect on this conditioning, and we can make strategic decisions to increase exposure to good inputs and limit exposure to negative ones. This is self-training, self conditioning, and results in behaviors that can appear to be autonomic, but whose origin are the conscious mind. While there is merit to giving more fair consideration of the panoply of conditioning influences over a lifetime, most of which are not our responsibility, and the unfairness of ignoring these influences is undoubtedly at the root of the no-free-will intent, it would nonetheless be incorrect to infer from these observations that the consciousness plays no role, that we are helpless in effecting the outcome of our lives. Not only would there be real consequences to people’s decision making if they were to accept this proposition, real harm they would experience in missed opportunity and other harms to society including crime, it is simply speaking not true, there are powers that we have at our conscious disposal, tools if you will, that can affect the outcome of our lives and it is certainly our responsibility as responsible members of society to make full use of those tools.

I'm unsure (unlike almost every other respondent :).  Some say that we cannot possibly have a free will, since we are comprised of sub-parts that are themselves subject to physical law. At the atomic level there does appear to be some form of semi-causal action that aligns with our intuition about self - something that clearly obeys laws of action while at the same time is random. Our personality is essentially all that is fixed about our behavior and thought patterns. That we have a personality at all seems to indicate that there is some degree of fixity of our mental states. But the question is whether our personality is completely fixed, or only partially? If we take the machine analogy again, its easy to see how we could have some responses that are deeply entrenched and hard to overturn. Other mental states may totter between two equally probable configurations (two equally stable states?). Perhaps thermal noise in the brain (random or coincidental firing of neurons, or that probabilistic/quantum action of atoms themselves) is enough to tip the balance between those states. I do wonder whether the nub of the question is actually a riddle - what could be purposeful and random at the same time while not being influenced by physical law?

Our genes, care-givers, peers, and other environmental influences all contribute to making us who we are. Where can one draw a line of principle between worthy luck and condemnable luck?Does the free will of Compatibilism preserve moral responsibility?Compatibilism claims that we have free will and that we are morally responsible even though all events are causally determined. We can define free will in terms of control in the action necessary for moral responsibility. To the deterministic aspect of Compatibilism, the source of the traits and dispositions of the agent can be traced back to conditions of origin that were completely beyond his control, having them is subject to luck. To the free will aspect of Compatibilism, agents are responsible for their actions if they intentionally modify themselves to have a certain set of traits and dispositions. But having the series of dispositions and values by which agents shape and modify their dispositions and values is subject to luck too. However, as scientists studied the Universe more and more, they found that Newton's laws (and it's derivatives) apply well to the Universe EXCEPT, at very small scales, and very large scales. We do know is that subatomic particles have their own rules, and we are begginning to understand them using Quantum theory. Quantum theory posits that sub atomic particles work non-dterministically. You cannot say for sure that a sub atomic particle being at a particular point in space-time. You can only compute the probability of it being there. I think it exists if you define it as I do, which is "the decision making process, as seen from the perspective of the decision making entity itself". There is nothing magical or supernatural about it, and there's no need for true non-determinism.   Imagine the computer in an autonomously controlled car.  The computer has to model the world around it, and use that model to predict such things as the behavior of other cars on the road (some of which may also be autonomous).  It includes itself in that model, of course.  But it doesn't try to predict its own behavior in the same way as it predicts the behavior of those other entities.  If it models its own decision making facility, it models it in a fundamentally different way than everything else in the model, since that is the one part that IT CONTROLS.  Trying to predict its own decisions would essentially put it in an infinite loop. Human brains do essentially the same thing.  When they think about their own thought process (and decision making ability), they are unable to describe it in the same way they describe other things.  It seems fundamentally "unpredictable", because it doesn't make sense to try to predict its own decisions.  So we get all confused about it and think its magic because it doesn't fit in our regular model of everything else. Ultimately, though, it is just a matter of perspective.

response.answer_text: It makes no difference whether or not we can justify free will by an objective measure. The existence of a feeling of voluntary control by itself is sufficient to invalidate the proposition of a deterministic universe. Not only would there be no survival advantage to such a phenomenon as a 'feeling' of free will (or any feeling for that matter) but it would not even be conceivable ontologically. It is to say that there is some advantage to having a shadow of a palm tree in a universe where no palm trees can ever exist. The solution I think hinges on a couple of things. First, that we are not literally one thing with one free will, we are many different sensorimotive agents sharing the same overlapping experience with both bottom up and top down participation. It's all us, but we are more than the sum of our parts. We are influenced by many different competing senses and motives but that doesn't mean that those processes are not also influenced by our overall perceptions and decisions. We can choose to focus on different impulses vying for our attention if we want.  The other thing is that just because we don't have absolute authority over our thoughts does not mean that we have no voluntary control over our thoughts or actions. If that was the case, there should be no reason for us to make any kind of distinction between the actions we take with our minds and and hands and the peristaltic contractions of our digestive tract. It would make no sense at all for us to have some kind of feeling for the difference between shooting someone in the face and sitting in on a park bench looking at the birds. if both circumstances were identically determined from outside of our awareness. It would be like imagining that a tree thinks that it's running around the forest all the time because there must be some kind of evolutionary advantage to it.  Think about it. It doesn't matter what a tree feels like as far as reproduction is concerned. Evolution is not teleological, it's teleonomy. An oak doesn't have to experience some fantasy of having some kind of impossible freedom in order to drop more acorns. It doesn't work that way. It's just that the trees who happen to drop more acorns by natural variation have a higher probability of populating the forest with more high-acorn-yielding trees. We should forget about this line of reasoning entirely, it's overreaching and distorts the role of evolutionary biology. If you can read this, there can be no other reason for it than that there is a possibility of making sense of it for your own purposes. In a deterministic universe, there would be no point to reading anything since all of your understanding was out of your control and your opinions would be provided for you. To doubt your own consciousness is not possible, because doubt is a form of consciousness. Free will is not the illusion, it is the disembodied voyeur which disqualifies free will on the grounds of second hand observations of the behaviors of objects in space. Free will is not an object in space, it is a subject through time.

Yes there is such a thing as free will. For example, moral actions. These actions are either uncaused, caused by another, or caused by oneself. First, there is no action that can be uncaused. If this were true it would go against the fundamental rational principle that every event has a cause. Second, a person’s actions cannot be caused by another. If that were true they wouldn't be 'personal' actions then would they? How would anyone be held responsible for their actions if they were always caused by something else? A person’s moral acts are actually caused by oneself. They are not caused by another or uncaused. They are not indeterminate or determined by another. It is always a freely chosen act when one could have done otherwise. One is only responsible for a choice if there was free will to avoid making it. All responsibility implies the ability to respond. Determinism destroys this human responsibility. But determinism proves itself to be false anyway. Denying that some actions can be free is self defeating. It shoots itself in the foot. If you are a complete determinist and follow the logic where it leads you must insist that both determinists and nondeterminists are determined to believe what they believe. But determinists believe self-determinists are wrong and ought to change their view. But “ought to change” implies freedom to change. This is contrary to determinism. C.S. Lewis also showed that for determinism to be true, there would have to be a rational basis for their thought. But if determinism is true, then there is no rational basis for thought, since all is determined by nonrational forces. So, if determinism claims to be true, then it must be false. Free will is alive and well. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. Or let them, it's your choice. ;)

Free Will, defined as the ability to have done otherwise, is not logically possible. All events must either be caused or uncaused, these are the only logical possibilities. In a universe where all events have prior causes, Free Will cannot exist as every outcome is completely determined by the given set of conditions; there is only one possible outcome. In a universe where some events do not have causes, Free Will still cannot exist as uncaused events cannot be willed into existence by a person, they would happen at random for no reason. These exhaust all possibilities, and therefore Free Will does not exist. This, however, does not undermine our own causal agency, we causally determine our actions, and as such still have the ability to determine our futures to our liking. I would like to add that since most of the world assumes Free Will to exist, the truth that it does not exist would have significant implications in the real world. Holding others morally or ethically accountable for their actions, good or bad, is no longer reasonable given that they could not have done otherwise. A person's choice isn't ultimately up to them, despite how much they agree with it. This would change the way we view others, hold grudges, or even hate others at all. We would still need to lock dangerous criminals away for the safety of others, but to punish them or hate them for being morally depraved would be wrong, it IS wrong. This may seem like a casual response on Quora, but it's in fact a pretty big deal. Unfortunately, many people aren't willing to hear this reasoning out. I hope someday that more answers like this will pop up, and more people will be willing to keep an open mind to ideas like Determinism. It might just change the world.

We as people have free will, but this is not to be confused with being able to control our outcome. What do I mean by this? I am free to go into a bank and apply for a 1.2 million dollar loan, but I can not control whether or not I receive this loan. Under string theory, there is a reality which exists out there in which I do get this loan.  I point to Chaos Theory and the Butterfly Effect: The philosophical argument that everything which exists in the world in interconnected. For example: something as small as the force of wind generated from a butterfly flapping its wings in Brazil can eventually build up and snow ball into a force causing a Typhoon in Japan. Under this philosophical argument, lets perform a thought experiment. You are walking down the crowded streets of New York City drinking your morning coffee. By accident someone bumps into you, this causes you to spill your hot coffee over a stranger standing to your left. You apologize but this man has become extremely angry. As you walk away this man gets a call from his girlfriend, but because he is now angry the two get in a phone fight which ultimately leads to their breakup. After their breakup, the man moves back home and the girlfriend moves to California.  Just think for a moment, the small act of someone bumping into on the street snowballed into life changing actions and consequences for complete strangers.  Now, Did these people exercise their free will or where their actions decided by forces beyond their control? You could not control getting bumped into by a stranger, the man could not control you would spill coffee on him and the girlfriend could not control her boyfriend being upset. Yet everyone actions here are dictated by these occurrences.  I argue we all still have free will here. You did not have to walk down that side of the street but you choose to, you did not have to get a coffee that morning but you wanted to. The man did not have to act angry with you, but he choose to let this emotion control him. He did not have to get upset with his girlfriend but he did. The girlfriend did not have to break up and move away, but she choose to. Though everything in the Universe is more interconnected than perhaps anyone might realize, if nothing else in life we are responsible for controlling our own self. I for one believe we are always given a choice, we do indeed have free will.

Interesting answers...  Oddly enough, the debate on the existence of free will didn't start until after it was put forward as an important concept.  Christian Theology was actually the main actor in bringing the notion of free will to the forefront of intellectual discourse. The "liberum arbitrium" is very important in (Catholic) theology because we see that man has a real power of cooperation with the grace of God.  God can (and does) even move our will from within but leaves us free to accept/choose that movement. On the philosophical side of things, it would be helpful to establish what the will is, and what it is for before analyzing a particular quality of its exercise, i.e. freedom.  For Aristotle (Nicomachean Ethics), the will is a power (dunamis), potency, or faculty - which in and of itself is not free unless you mean "free" as in "free beer."  Choice, on the other hand, which is an act of the will, implies a certain amount of freedom.  You do not choose what is imposed upon you, so, for Aristotle, you do not choose your "end" (telos - in the philosophical sense).  You cannot choose whether or not you are attracted to something good, what you can choose is whether or not you will respond to that attraction.  And responding to the attraction of that which is good requires a choice of means - that is where our ethical freedom lies, in the means we choose to attain our end, which is the good we are attracted to. One of the things Nietzsche drew everyone's attention to was what he called the "will to power."  While our will is also what enables us to be efficient, to move things forward, to be "willful," that is not its primary function.  The primary function of our will is to form acts of spiritual love, and that is what gives us the greatest amount of interior strength. Loving is being moved or attracted by another person, and all the love songs ever written bear witness to the fact that this is the strongest force that exists.  And though love is incredibly gripping in its capacity to move us, it is terribly vulnerable at the same time - the slightest misunderstanding, the slightest breach of trust, wounds love and causes it to lose its strength, and causes us to lose our sense of direction and purpose.  So to fortify this love, we must regularly choose and re-choose whatever means will enable us to remain attached to the end (person) who attracts us. I think we realize the existence of our freedom to the extent that we realize how much it depends upon us and our choices to remain attached to the person we love.

I wrote a critique, which I pasted below, of a well known video which shows some experiments preformed by neuroscientists that supposedly "disproved free will" (this video is discussed on some other posts, you can find links there or via google). Basically, they showed that when we place a man in a scanner and ask him to, at random, select between pushing the button placed in his right hand from the button placed in the right, they can predict via brain-imaging which button he will push (left or right) about 6 second before he makes a decisions and press it.  The video makes it seem that, given the scientific findings explained in the video, there is no other belief or theory that’s acceptable besides the idea that “our subconscious brains drive our decisions and our couscous selves just follow it’s command.” This is false— there are multiple other logically sound positions a person can take which allow us to logically believe in free will even with the standing science surrounding the debate. Let me point out a few of these stances: The Brain Region Question:Just because we've shown that neuroscience can predict about 6 seconds before we know what we will do the actual act of what we will do when we participate in randomly clicking a button in our hand, this does not mean they can predict other actions which require different brain situations. This is where the author steps into theory. This experiment shows what our brains do in a very specific setting and notes that certain brain regions “light up” long before we know what we will do and that these brain regions show which of two options will be chosen by us consciously. It does not prove the brain acts like this in other, very different settings.  Yes, it shows that when we randomly select between two choices our brains decide long before “we” (the couscous us) decides, but what proves we might not rely on some subconscious part(s) of our brains to help us decide who to marry, what car to buy, and how to write comments on Quora. It’s obvious to those studying neuroscience that we use different parts of the brain for different activities— what if one part or parts holds our “free will” and we only access it when doing certain tasks? What if all of our brain has wired into it a “free will” function, but we don’t use it when randomly choosing between two buttons? What if our brains use a kind of subconscious auto-pilot for making some decisions (like clicking randomly between two buttons) but use a “free will overdrive” when it comes to different, more important decisions— like moral decisions?  Only more neuroscience and philosophy will tell!  The Cogito Model:The Cogito Model is another option in the array of theories that explain the mechanisms of the brain and the possibility of free will. This model shows how we can exist in a way that is not deterministic, (i.e. in a way that allows free will). In a way, I alluded to something like the Cogito Model when I said “what if all of our brain has wired into it a “free will” function.” The link below will dive into how quantum mechanics (a well established set of observations in physics) plays a role in our neuronal activity (in our brains) and so allows the idea that "we are in the drivers seat" (as opposed to the idea that "our brains control us.") The Cogito Model. It is a very in-depth article, so I'll point out some of the main features for light-readers:  a) The scientific community has proven that particles on the quantum mechanical scale not deterministic, or, in other words, they are not caused by something which will fix a certain behavior or outcome: they are random, non determined in nature. (If you'd like to learn more about this, check out the MinutePhysics video on this entitled "Can We Predict Everything?" just google the title.) b) Our brains, which are composed of neurons, function at a level so small it is in touch with the quantum mechanical.  c) This provides the logical idea that our brains, at some level, are random or have access to randomness, which could allow us to make decisions freely.  (That sound's a little weird, I know, but if you think about it— about the brain being able to have a "starting point" from a place of randomness, you'd be able to logically conclude that we can really decide freely what we will do given nothing is causing our decision, no past set up or force since there is a launching pad of "chaotic noise" or randomness from which our brains get to be creative and free). Another interesting bit to know is well expressed in this quote:"[...] experiments show that the unconscious mind initiates seemingly voluntary acts, some as much as 0.35 seconds earlier than conscious awareness. Back in the 1980s, Benjamin Libet concluded that we have no free will as far as the initiation of our movements are concerned, but that we had a kind of cognitive "veto" to prevent the movement at the last moment; we can't start it, but we can stop it." (Quoted from 8 Things We Simply Don't Understand About the Human Brain).  So we could say free will is a component we invoke during the last steps of our decisions. Why choose a philosophy which makes your choice irrelevant in the first place?Our mere ability to have this discussion suggests the importance of consciousness, choice, and the value of humans. The alternative is a deterministic worldview which treats us like billiard balls rather than the complex choice bearing individuals we appear to be based on the evidence available to us as human, philosophers, and scientists. The World is a Stage:We both act in the world and are acted upon. Ultimately, to my knowledge, we can't verify via science either way. However, irrespective whether free will exists or not--we should act as if free will exists. (Which incidentally seems to be the larger question....at least to me....). If only because it makes life more enjoyable and fulfilling, but also because it makes ideas like responsibility a core. It give meaning to our desires to protect women and minorities from the dehumanization that others might. This resonates with the power and possibility that lies in the universe and in humanity. The Value of HopeFurther, the argument for hope is compelling. That a world with hope and acting as if hope is a possibility makes more sense than acting as if there is an all controlling force in our chemistry. If we act like that, we would resemble some of the scenes from Lord of the Flies--because it would be a world of no value in humans, no responsibility, no accountability, and no justice. Argument Fail: Science Whether Chemistry or Biology Can't Exclude Freewill and ChoiceThe core of this question has a far, far larger burden of proof. To say that genes, biology, or chemistry shape who we are doesn't mean they determine who we are or to what extent that is the case (its a continuum if you will). This means that 99% of the answers here simply don't answer the question. For instance, chemistry wouldn't be able to say if choice existed or not--it simply is not geared to make a determination of this philosophical query. If there is a study from chemistry or elsewhere that says otherwise, I would like to read it. The hidden or embedded premise that "chemistry can explain everything about humans and life" is a bit dubious. As such, chemistry in one sense begs the question of choice--almost in the same way that math begs the same question with respect to this answer. Chemistry isn't a science capable of detecting human choice--which suggest using it as evidence is a bit of a fool's errand. However, the unpredictability of scientific results (aka the margin of error in experiments which involve human subjects and perhaps even animal subjects) suggests some force other than chemistry is at work, which further suggest chemistry alone is a poor tool to determine the answer--and further suggests a detectable degree of indeterminacy--which might just be choice. (I recently compiled some quotes from John Polkinghorne on this issue, which I encourage you to read here Investigating Science, Quantum Mechanics, and Free Will ) Also, I imagine despite the correlations, that many chemists and even neuro-biologists still believe in the notions of human choice. If you read the literature on soft determinism its far, far more convincing than the literature on hard determinism which relies on radical conspiracy theories which are extremely hyperbolic and lack connection to how we experience reality in our daily lives. Libet Experiments Don't Provide Answers:Tim Bayne from Oxford in Free Will and Modern Science points out that the Libet experiments are really looking at issues of indifference rather than deliberation (two separate categories of wills or intents), so the experiments aren't the "ideal exemplars of free will that Libet takes them to be": But although Libet-actions involve an act of will they do not involve deliberation—at least, not immediately prior to the action. In my terms, they are examples of disinterested agency, for the agent has no reason to flex their wrist at one particular time rather than the other, or to flex it in one way rather than another. Indeed, Libet experiments are explicitly constructed so as to minimize the rational constraints under which the subject acts. We might think of Libet-actions as manifesting the liberty of indifference. He continues by noting Libets assessment of the type II readiness potential is misguided and flawed: As Mele (2009) and Roskies (2011) have observed, we simply do not know. Our ignorance on this point derives from the fact that the RP is measured by a process known as ‘backaveraging.’ Because the RP on any one trial is obscured by neural noise, what is presented as ‘the RP data’ is determined by averaging the data collected on a large number of trials. In order to compute this average, the EEG recordings on different trials need to be aligned, and this requires some fixed point—such as the onset of muscle activity or some other observable behaviour on the part of the subject—that can be identified across trials. Any RPs that are not followed by an action simply won’t be measured, and so we don’t know how robust the correlation between the RP and Libet-actions is.15 As such, the conclusions from the Libet's studies as well as those papers influenced by the conclusions must be viewed in a very critical light.Experience:When picking your worldview on this question--it just makes sense to err on the side of choice. Determinism requires humans to act like robots, but the experience of life isn't robotic, despite patterns of behavior (realize I'm carving out distinctive middle ground here). Infinite regresses on other possibilities don't seem particularly constructive--except to say that we have amazing imaginations which tremendously powerful and flexible engines. Moreover, the experiences of situations of lack of control versus situations of relative freedom are vastly different. Often the internal feelings and calculations as well as the external demeanor of people who have good self-concept and self-control versus those who are addicted is vastly different (and there is a broad continuum of steps between one situation and the other). In the case of drug addicts we literally know much of what chemical influence does to control, but by contrast the experience of human existence is in sharp contrast to those experiences (Frankfurt seems to make a similar argument). * Further, psychologists say that our brains decision-making resembles a man on top of a elephant (metaphorically). In that sense, we are still in control, just the ways in which humans can exercise that control are limited to 1. self-control 2. will and determination 3. self-motivation 4. accountability. Moreover, neuro-biologists talk about two systems of thought--one more intuitive and instinctual, the other more reflective. The act and experience of reflection isn't really captured by the determinists. The human experience of choice and deliberation includes focus, attention, degree of will (volition or intention), among other deeply complex and intertwined experiences of human conciousness. To deny these forces seems to belie reality. Mele highlights some of those experiences: Such agents are capable of modifying the strengths of their desires in the service of their normative judgments, of bringing their emotions into line with relevant judgments, and of mastering motivation that threatens (sometimes via the biasing of practical or theoretical reasoning) to produce or sustain beliefs in ways that would violate their principles for belief-acquisition and retention. They are capable, moreover, of rationally assessing and revising their values and principles, of identifying with values of theirs on the basis of informed, critical reflection, and of intentionally fostering new values and pro-attitudes in themselves in accordance with their considered evaluative judgments. Presumably, most readers of this essay have each of these capacities in some measure. All such capacities are bypassed in cases of pro-attitude engineering of the sort at issue. In such cases, new pro-attitudes are not generated via an exercise or an activation of agents’ capacities for control over their mental lives; rather, they are generated despite the agents’ capacities for this. Earlie in the essay, Mele calls attention to the metaphor of driving a car, which I think is apt for contrast: Control is a topic of much discussion in the literature on autonomy. Sometimes it is claimed that agents have no control at all if determinism is true. That claim is false. When I drive my car (under normal conditions), I am in control of the turns it makes, even if our world happens to be deterministic. I certainly am in control of my car’s movements in a way in which my passengers and others are not. In the same way, the experience of being in control of decisions and our lives mirrors this position (the alternative would be the life of a television across which visuals and energy were flashed, but someone else was in control of the remote). This isn't how we experience reality. In fact, were humans to take this perspective it would only lead to regression, irresponsibility, and isolation. Such a shift would only re-ify the truth claim that we control and need to control our behaviors. Category Mistake/Faulty Assumptions:To examine human conciousness based on causality is itself a category mistake, according to an astute reviewer: The feeling of free will is so completely different from the feeling attending perception of ordinary cause-effect phenomena, that to apply the word "cause" to the former might well be due to some inept attempt to articulate something distinct from all other experiences, but using words appropriate only to those other experiences. Perhaps the feeling of free will is inherently incapable of articulation. A philosophical writer would at least consider that a scientific study of free will in terms of cause-effect relations is inherently misguided. Rationality Transcends Causality J.F. Johnston highlights: As Steven Pinker observes, morality, consciousness and free will are "deep enigmas" and "elusive quantities [sic] whose origins still remain wrapped insubstantial mystery...." (28) This honest admission tells us that we have reached the limit of science and have crossed over into philosophy--specifically, into what Ernst Cassirer called "the philosophy of symbolic forms." (29) A creature constituted solely by the physical flux of nature could not stand outside of, and bring order and meaning to, that flux. Mind cannot be identical with the matter it describes. Humans are convinced that they make conscious choices as they live their lives. But instead it may be that the brain just convinces itself that it made a free choice from the available options after the decision is made. The idea was tested out by tricking subjects into believing that they had made a choice before the consequences of that choice could actually be seen. In the test, people were made to believe that they had taken a decision using free will – even though that was impossible. The idea that human beings trick themselves into believing in free will was laid out in a paper by psychologists Dan Wegner and Thalia Wheatley nearly 20 years ago. They proposed the feeling of wanting to do something was real, but there may be no connection betweeen that. The study builds on that work and says that the brain rewrites history when it makes its choices, changing our memories so that we believe we wanted to do something before it happened. In one of the studies undertaken by Adam Bear and Paul Bloom, of Yale University, the test subjects were shown five white circles on a computer monitor. They were told to choose one of the circles before one of them lit up red. The participants were then asked to describe whether they’d picked the correct circle, another one, or if they hadn’t had time to actually pick one. Statistically, people should have picked the right circle about one out of every five times. But they reported getting it right much more than 20 per cent of the time, going over 30 per cent if the circle turned red very quickly. The scientists suggest that the findings show that the test subjects’ minds were swapping around the order of events, so that it appeared that they had chosen the right circle – even if they hadn’t actually had time to do so. The idea of free will may have arisen because it is a useful thing to have, giving people a feeling of control over their lives and allowing for people to be punished for wrongdoing. Source: https://www.google.co.in/amp/www.independent.co.uk/news/science/free-will-could-all-be-an-illusion-scientists-suggest-after-study-that-shows-choice-could-just-be-a7008181.html%3Famp
