Oh boy, the tough questions are starting to show up in my feed. This’ll be good for people’s perception of my mental health. I’m gonna be that guy who says no, the idea of free will is kind of nonsense. Let me lay out why I say that. In order for you to truly have control, which is necessary for free will, it’s my opinion that the results of your actions cannot be random. Sure, you can choose whether to call “heads” or “tails” when someone flips a coin, but it’s not an informed decision with some kind of intentionality behind it, even if you’ve rationalized some idea about why your answer is better than the other. Even though you’re able to freely make that choice, I don’t call that “free will” because you have no control over the outcome, and you cannot logically be held responsible for the consequences of being right or being wrong when the result is random. People will argue me on this point, but for the sake of understanding my argument you’ll have to accept, at least for the moment, that free will is only free when you’re making an informed decision with established consequences for each option. Now when we’re making more concrete decisions, we feel as though we are manipulating the outcome. After all, if you’re debating getting the large ice cream instead of the small one, the actual size of the dessert isn’t what makes you pause - you’re thinking about the stomach ache you might get if you eat too much, or the extra pounds you’re afraid to see on the scale tomorrow morning. Decision-making is all about weighing outcomes and consequences against one another, and we feel the most secure in making a decision when we feel as though we know the consequences of all of the options, so that we can judge those consequences effectively. It’s my opinion that this idea, that we can know the effects of our options and make a decision based on those outcomes, is nonsense. There’s always a chance that the consequences we anticipated are completely different from the actual outcome, and an even greater chance that there will be consequences that we didn’t consider, even that we could never have anticipated. The interactions of the things we don’t control with the things we think we do control always lead to unpredictable results. What’s more, the way cause and effect tend to ripple out means our decisions have consequences so distant from us that we’ll never even know we caused them. Consider: you’re driving down a highway, running late for an interview that could land you your dream job. The traffic is pretty dense, not much room between the cars. The dude in the truck in front of you is going way slower than the lane next to you, but there’s a brief opening in that lane after the next car moves past you. It’d be a risky move, but you could probably make it over in time. Do you switch lanes? If you do switch lanes, the person you’re pulling in front of is going to have to hit their brakes a little, suddenly. That means the person behind them will have to hit their brakes, too; and the person behind them, and so on, because the traffic is so dense. Those slow-downs build on each other, and this is what causes those weird delays you get on the highway where you keep expecting to see a massive, ugly accident but never do, and it is entirely possible under the conditions I described for a single car changing lanes too abruptly can add as much as a 15-minute delay to the travel times.[1] Maybe there’s a father behind you who’s going to miss his son’s first baseball game because of that backup you caused. Maybe there’s somebody with a medical emergency in the car trying to get to the hospital as quickly as possible - who knows what the effect on that situation could be. Maybe it’s not that dramatic, but a couple hundred people get home from work a little later and a litter grumpier because traffic was bad. Very few people are going to argue in any way that those things are your fault, despite your decision to switch lanes being a direct cause of them. You certainly never intended any of those consequences when you changes lanes, you just wanted to get to your interview. You didn’t know - you couldn’t have known. And that’s exactly why I say you ultimately didn’t have free will in that situation, even though the choice to move over was completely under your control. You had the apparent free will to decide whether or not to take the action you did, but you were acting under a false set of assumptions about the effects of that decision - not unlike a person who thinks that a coin flip is less likely to land the same way it landed before, or that the side of the coin that’s up before the flip affects the outcome. What’s more, that false set of assumptions isn’t something that you created yourself, it’s what was suggested to you by the world, by society, by the context, by previous experience, and so on. You had good reason to think the way you did, but those reasons were external to you, and they led you astray. Our frame of reference is so small and so limited that we don’t have true control over much of anything, and we’d almost certainly make fundamentally different decisions if we really could foresee all the consequences. That doesn’t sound like “free will” to me. Footnotes[1] Traffic jam mystery solved by mathematicians

The fact that Adam and Eve had a choice to make in the Garden of Eden shows beyond all doubt that mankind was created with a free will. The first couple chose to sin, and that choice has plunged the entire world into spiritual darkness leading to our need of salvation. Through it all, mankind has retained his free will, and we will retain free will in heaven. Is it possible that people in heaven can exercise their free will to sin again and get kicked out of heaven? No, it is not possible. To back up a bit, we need an acceptable definition of free will. We have free will, but not in the way most people think. Our freedom consists in the fact that we are free to choose according to our desires. As long as we have a minimum of two available options, we must make a choice, and we will always do so according to our strongest desire. But, in the case of a fallen sinner, he or she is not at liberty to choose according to righteousness. This is what Jesus means when He says that the one who sins â€œis a slave to sinâ€ (John 8:34). This is not the language of â€œfree willâ€ as people typically think of it. The unregenerate person has a sinful nature; he is not just inclined to sin but driven by sinful impulses. It is perhaps helpful to say, â€œWe are free to choose what we want but not free to want what we ought.â€ This greatly limits our â€œfreedomâ€ because the list of things we want (as sinners) coincides with whatever pleases our sinful impulses. Our choices are for things that will ultimately destroy us (Proverbs 14:12). As Paul says, â€œOh, what a miserable person I am! Who will free me from this life that is dominated by sin and death?â€ (Romans 7:24, NLT). When we are saved, we are liberated from our natural bondage to sin. The Holy Spirit sovereignly regenerates us and in grace gives us the ability to want what we ought to want, namely, forgiveness, salvation, and the lordship of Christ. When we trust in Jesus for salvation, we begin a moral progression, a journey toward holiness in which we put to death daily the sinful impulses that reside within us and strive toward godliness. In heaven we will be completely devoid of sin; our only desires will be for the things of Godâ€”things that bless us, fulfill us, and give us life. This is true liberty (see Romans 8:21). We will retain our free will in heaven, but our will is sanctified there. The sin nature will be gone.

For me, the question is not so much whether or not free will exists, but how we can define it such that it is meaningful and functional for the way it is commonly used and attributable to neurological processes. This is not an easy task because it seems to be an oxymoron. The "free" part doesn't appear to be logically compatible with the "will" part, not to mention the deterministic or indeterminist reality in which it is supposed to exist. What we need is something neurologically compatible which can be responsible for moral and other sorts of agency. For those reasons, I prefer instead to talk about self-determination. A system is self-determining when its decisions have some autonomous component, not determined by something outside of it. The system might be deterministically or indeterministically formed or structured, such as the way the brain has evolved as a combination of the expression of its genes and the use of the biological material for that expression. The brain is also partly structured by use and disuse, as well as its input and feedback regarding its output. This is often referred to in the literature as its plasticity. Brains also have a biofeedback process. And its this biofeedback process which I believe is the strongest candidate for what we want to call self-determination. I would bet that the more complex the brain, along with its Encephalization quotient, which frees the brain to greater degrees from direct connections to its sensory input and motor output, for thinking. Because of its biofeedback and plasticity, thoughts can be redirected on themselves and change the brain without dominant external influences. This, of course, is just one possible neurobiological story, and it would require more formal observations, measurements, and experimentation. At the cognitive and psychological level, I believe self-determination becomes possible when we can consider hypotheticals and counterfactuals, not so much representationally, but systematically. The logical formation of a negation makes these possible, as well as disjunctive reasoning, which is the basis for choice. Because I can negate, I can consider hypotheticals and counterfactuals. Because I can consider hypotheticals and counterfactuals, I can consider disjunctive possibilities and preferences, both representationally and, more importantly for self-determination, in my behavioural responses. I can do either A or B. If part of my biofeedback is dedicated to considering A or B, whether I choose A or B is to some degree autonomous and unpredictable outside the system (such as by observing my behaviour). If that's not what we mean by free will, I don't know what is. What would be experimentally interesting is to contrast disjunctive choices, in the one case with obvious and extreme coercive pressures, and in the other case without those pressures. If the experiment were set up right, the outcome should be much less predictable without the extreme coercive pressures. I would interpret that outcome as evidence for free will. With the right experiment, it could be run and compared for a number of different species, and in turn, their brains could be neurologically compared to explain the difference in the results. It should be noted that cognitive science, neuroscience, and even philosophy of mind are not my primary fields of interest. I would be interested to hear how those who do study those fields weigh in on the question and my proposed experimental approach to it. I may very well be missing some fundamental facts in those fields.

Science demonstrates that all interactions of matter--including all events in the human brain--are sufficiently caused by previous events. If we know enough about the laws that govern these interactions and the current state of the universe, we would be able to exactly predict any future event. Does this mean that the doctrine of "agency" or "free will" is false, since all human choices are predetermined by the laws of physics? We know from the scriptures that God can exactly predict the future, but we also know from the scriptures that we have our moral agency to decide our future. There must be a solution to this problem, but there is as yet no generally-accepted solution. The Spirit and the Body Everything we think and feel is probably correlated with some physical changes in the brain. And, really, this shouldn't surprise the LDS, since they do not believe that "mind"/"spirit" and "body" are two totally separate and utterly un-similar things (See Cartesian fallacy): There is no such thing as immaterial matter. All spirit is matter, but it is more fine or pure, and can only be discerned by purer eyes; We cannot see it; but when our bodies are purified we shall see that it is all matter. (D&C 131:7-8) Thus, in LDS theology there is no spirit/matter dichotomy. Spirit is matter, though less easily detected by mortal eyes. If a spiritual experience or a "thought" from our spirit/mind is to have an effect upon a mortal being, it's not surprising to find detectable physical changes in the gross "non-spiritual" matter which we can study. You won't detect the actor (the 'spirit matter'), necessarily, but you might expect to see the effect of the action (on the 'body matter'). Newtonian Determinism A question that is likely to create an argument in any LDS Sunday School class anywhere in the world is, "Does God perfectly know the future?" Half the class will insist that he does, because the scriptures are clear: O how great the holiness of our God! For he knoweth all things, and there is not anything save he knows it. 2 Nephi 9:20 The other half will insist that this is not possible, since this would destroy the free agency of man, which is also clear: Therefore, cheer up your hearts, and remember that ye are free to act for yourselves—to choose the way of everlasting death or the way of eternal life. 2 Nephi 10:23 But God’s knowledge is not really the question anyway. The real question relative to free will involves the nature of physical and spiritual law — is it deterministic or indeterministic? The Universe is said to be "deterministic" if, given the state of the Universe at one point in time, there is only one state possible at a later point in time. The Newtonian world view was deterministic. It concluded that, given the present positions, velocities, and other properties of every bit of matter, field, and (we would add) spirit, the future values for these variables are completely specified. Thus, the orbits of the planets, the weather, the rise and fall of nations, or the outcome of every love affair is already determined, based on the current state of the universe. It is hard to see how free agency can exist in such an environment. Quantum Uncertainty The alternative to a deterministic Universe is a Universe in which, given the state of the Universe at one point in time, more that one state is possible at a later point in time. We call such a Universe "indeterministic." Since the early 20th century, it has been clear that the fundamental laws of the Universe are quantum mechanical in nature. In quantum mechanics, the present state of the Universe may precisely determine a probability distribution, but, ultimately, the future state of the Universe will involve a random selection from among the allowed possibilities. The future is always partially uncertain. This is the majority view of the interpretation of quantum theory, but it is not the only view. As the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophystates, The scientific evidence for quantum mechanics is sometimes said to show that determinism is false. Quantum theory is indeed very well confirmed. However, there is nothing approaching a consensus on how to interpret it, on what it shows us with respect to how things are in the world. Indeterministic as well as deterministic interpretations have been developed, but it is far from clear whether any of the existing interpretations is correct. [1] But does quantum mechanics do anything to help the situation relative to free agency? We must remember that quantum mechanics is partly deterministic — the determination of the probabilities for each possible outcome — and partly indeterministic — the final random selection of one state out of all the possibilities. Since the ultimate selection process is random, it is no different than the process of flipping a coin. The quantum world view, with each decision slave to the outcome of a coin toss, seems less conducive to free will than does the deterministic world view. What Is Free Agency? The existence or non-existence of free will has deeply troubled Mormon and non-Mormon philosophers for centuries, and the problem shows no sign of resolving itself. One Mormon philosopher, Blake Ostler, [2] has suggested that there is a third possibility between determinism and indeterminism. This is the "creative synthesis" suggested by philosopher and theologian Charles Hartshorne. In this view, the moment of decision itself creates a new entity that did not exist in the previous moment, one that is affected by the decision process and that contributes to the outcome of the decision process in a deterministic but unpredictable way. This, it is suggested, is what we call "free will." On the other hand, a Mormon physicist, Ronald Hellings, [3] has argued that Hartshorne’s description of "creative synthesis" sounds suspiciously like a simple non-linear process, a completely deterministic thing that engineers and scientists encounter and solve all the time. In Hellings’ view, free agency should be thought of as the name for the deterministic causes that arise inside an individual’s uncreated intelligence. Determinism is required, according to Hellings, in order to allow those causes to truly make the decision and not have it stolen away at the last moment by a random flip of an electron in someone's brain. Yes. But the very meaning of free-will will differ among the creeds. To Rabbinic Jews, the substance of all things, and their properties, and the laws that regulate and determine their activities, were created by God out of His free will. Indeed, the very act of creation, as told in Genesis, tells us that man was created in God's image; referring to our ability to reason and exercise grammar to communicate...not anthropomorphism. God could have created the Universe in a different way and change the laws that govern it. There is no necessary inherent order in the cosmos. The concept of Nature as a self contained system is profane to Jews...we are free to use our thinking, reasoning, capabilities -- even if some of us are better at it than others. Our free-will is unbounded except by laws that govern peaceful coexistence as we exercise that free-will...but, again, we can choose to obey or transgress those laws. Christians generally, in contrast, harbor an Alexandrian Hellenized belief structure wherein a universe created by God followed Aristotlean design: Aristotle’s deity was deprived of free will, and the logos shattered. For Aristotle, divinity and predictability were concepts that went hand in hand. Just as Aristotle perceived nature, Aristotle’s deity acted through a predictable sequence of causes and effects. God, according to any Greek philosopher, could not have suddenly changed his mind and decided to create a world - or extinguish it. For Aristotle, change was a trait of human beings, not of gods or of nature. Creation of the universe would have implied a change in the divine mind, which could only be a function of intentionality or will, a characteristic Aristotle’s theology did attribute to its deity. Aristotle relied on his astronomical observations to prove that the universe was eternal and that it has coexisted with the eternal-and-devoid-of-free-will deity. This premise led Aristotle and many other philosophers in antiquity to conclude that the cosmos never had a beginning. So, as we can see from the above description, the meaning of free-will depends upon your orientation - do you incline towards an Alexandrian Hellenized version or a Babylonian Hebrew version of free-will...the gravity of that knowledge affects everything you do, and how you engage with others in this world.

A chess program thinks for a moment, its algorithms running at inconceivable speeds. Split seconds pass by while it assesses billions of potential moves and counter moves. It finally chooses, and in an instant you realize that you've been crushed again by the computer. This is the shared experience of any chess player who bravely challenges the world's top chess programs. Even the best human players can no longer avoid this experience.  Yet do humans get the last laugh? Does free will put us above such rudimentary processing machines? It seems that way, but logic says otherwise. Choice When you think of free will, inevitably you're brought to the human idea of choice. Yet choice itself proves nothing. The chess playing program chooses every time it decides upon a move. The choices just happen to be the result of a complicated algorithm capable of beating human chess players.  You need to illustrate that you are free to choose to logically illustrate free will. This should be easy you might say. But I promise you, its not only difficult ~ it is logically impossible! Prior Causes No matter how impressive the playing skills of a chess computer, we know that every choice it makes is entirely the result of a prior cause. The program takes a series of data (moves, position, time, theory) and calculates its best move. There is no freedom involved, each decision is entirely chained to the data. Change the inputs, and the choices it makes will change. We can definitively say that any choice that is the result of a prior cause is not the result of freedom - it is the result of that cause. Just like the billiard ball whose motion can be traced back through a series of prior causes, so can each of the moves of a chess playing program provided you can understand its coding.  What about you? How many of the choices you make are the result of prior causes versus free will? Consider how much freedom you had in your choice to think about chess playing programs just now. Or purple monkeys. Both ideas were just imput into your mind because you read these words. These are prior causes, which by definition are void of free will. But take it a step further. What about every preference you have? Did you choose your favorite color or is it an existing preference derived from elements outside of your influence? Though your preferences can change, do you control this? I'f you prefer the color blue, can you genuinely force yourself to prefer the color purple? Any choice you make based on a preference, whether it be something simple like an apple over an orange, or more complex that mixes many preferences like a particular career path - each time these choices are developed entirely on preexisting data that your brain processes. You are capable of choosing, but you are not capable of changing the elements that influence those choices any more than you can change the past or that chess playing programs can alter their inputs. Yet you say, I am free to choose an orange even if I prefer an apple. But what would cause you to choose against your preferences? As soon as you can answer that, you are back to another cause, and in fact just replacing one cause for another. As long as there is a cause, just like with the chess playing program, there can be no free will. Life Experience With every decision, you have a lifetime of experience to rely on. Yet all your wisdom and moral leanings are based on what you've developed up that this point in life. Your values, no matter how they are developed, are mere inputs that influence each decision in the same manner that the chess playing program uses certain principles to decide its best move. You may argue that your moral compass isn't based on any life experience, you were born a certain way, or your soul defines who you are. But what freedom did you have to be born a certain way or with a particular soul? Even if these elements represent the overwhelming source of what influences your choices, you are still not free to choose them at birth any more than you are free to choose your parents or your genetic composition. Illustrative Example Sam Harris offers an astoundingly simple yet profound experiment in his book "Free Will" that demonstrates how easy it is to overlook a lack of free will. To paraphrase: There are over 2 million cities around the world. Pick a particular city. Think about the process that just took place in your brain. Were you free to choose any city on the planet? You would have to know the name of every city for that to be even possible. You were therefore not free to choose any city.  But even among those cities that you do know, were you free to choose any of them? Did you consciously review every city you know the name of and rule most of them out? What naturally occurs is a small selection of cities appear in your thoughts, and you chose from among this group.  But what causes this particular list of cities to appear? Perhaps you visited these cities recently, read about them, or saw a picture of one on the wall. Maybe they are places you have lived, saw on television, or heard mentioned in a nearby conversation. What is important to note here is that you have no conscious control over the small selection of cities that popped into your thoughts. The entire selection you had to choose from is the result of prior causes, many of which you might not even be able to explain. Take it a step further. What made you choose the particular city from this small group? Personal preference? Randomness? It had to be something. And whatever it was, it had a cause. If it had a prior cause, its was not free. You can analyze the process of any choice in this manner. It is always either a prior cause, an external factor, complete randomness, or a combination of all three. Yet in none of these areas does logic permit free will Back to Billiards Consider for a moment a game of billiards. A shot is taken that sets multiple balls into motion. If the exact same setup could be reconstructed, and the exact same initial shot taken, the balls would end up in the identical position. The laws of physics do not permit otherwise.  Compare this to the manner in which you define your choices. If you could live your entire life up to this moment the with the exact same set of experiences and circumstances, would you choose a different city in the experiment above or the same one?  If the answer is the same, then you understand how you are entirely locked into your choice by the sum of all your prior experiences and preferences. If the answer is different, then there must be a variable that changed, and this new variable is a new cause. You are thus replacing one cause for another, but still tied to a prior cause. And if you assume your answer could be different because it may be entirely random, then you are still left void of freedom. What is Human Choice? When you follow the logic, choice falls entirely within the confines of one or more of three distinct elements, none of which allow for free will: 1 - the influence of prior causes2 - external influences3 - randomness What part of choice falls outside of any of these? It is difficult to accept, but in any given moment, you have no control over what you will choose next.  Even if you stop reading at this moment and walk away in disgust, this is a choice that is the result of preexisting preferences and  biases that elicit emotions with regard to the topic. You did not consciously choose to like or dislike this any more than you consciously chose to like or dislike a particular food. And if you still don't agree, imagine that you lived your entire life over again up to this very moment. Would you possibly feel any different? Does free will exist? Free will and causality cannot co-exist – one or the other has to go. You can’t have it both ways: Either everything is caused - in which case we don’t have free will.Or we do have free will – in which case not everything is caused.The easy option is to stick with causality and deny the existence of free will. But if you deny free will you are negating everything that we value in human existence: love, kindness, generosity, selflessness, altruism, artistic and literary creativity etc. etc. All these become hollow and empty if they are caused, determined and unchosen rather than optional, elective and voluntary. Deny free will and you deny our humanity. What kind of person would that? So how do you argue in favour the existence of free will? If free will is to be preserved, then it is necessary to counter determinism. And that means digging deep until you find a flaw in causality: You must undermine the philosophical assumptions causality is built on! So, what are the philosophical assumptions underpinning causality? There are two possibilities: Causality is an inbuilt aspect of realityCausality is a methodology which we create in order to get a handle on realityIf causality is an inbuilt aspect of reality, then free will is impossible. But if causality is a methodology of our own creation, then free will become possible. If causality is something created by mind, then we have the choice where to apply it where not to apply it. And one area where we should not apply causality is to complex systems. We should not attempt to apply causality to complex systems. Complex systems have feedback loops where an effect is turned back on itself in such a way as to becomes its own cause. Trying to apply causality in these circumstances is pointless, futile and frankly - misguided… In complex systems it becomes impossible to separate cause from effect When we stop applying causality to complex systems, we have made the first step towards rescuing free will from the clutches of determinism. That is because the factors that influence the choices we make using free will are complex – so complex that we cannot even start to fathom then. And we shouldn’t even try. Life exists on the cusp between order and chaos. So too does consciousness. And this boundary is never explored more profoundly by consciousness, than when it exercises free will to instigate an action - and in that way to implement its intention… Life, consciousness and intention operate on the cusp between order and chaos Causality works with simple systems where what is ordered and what is random is clear cut and straightforward. As a methodology, causality breaks down, when you try to apply it to the cusp between order and chaos - where cause and effect become indistinguishable and identical. Life and Free Will are complex systems where causality falls apart… ________________________________________________________________________ Links to my related Quora answers: Time and space are artefacts of mind Fundamental Philosophical assumptions Questions Science can’t answer Determinism and the biosphere Free will and Humanity

Question at time of answering: Does free will exist? Normally I like to give a short yes/no answer, followed by a longer explanation. I am not going to this time because this is one of those questions where having weird ideas about the right answer can lead one to being more wrong than if one maintained an intuitive belief in the wrong answer. Google definition of “Free Will”: the power of acting without the constraint of necessity or fate; the ability to act at one's own discretion. I’ll use this definition for the rest of my answer because it seems to match the common usage of the phrase reasonably well. I won’t make much mention of the bit about fate, though, because while fate has historically been the primary opponent to free will, I believe it has fallen out of fashion in modern academic discourse. If one wants to clarify the concept of free will, the key word is “necessity”. Any actions or decisions made by necessity are outside of outside of the domain of free will, the others have the potential to be within it. Now, there are other constraints, unconscious actions for example tend not to be described as acts of free will, but this is more of a filter then an all-encompassing barrier and therefore of less relevance to the question of whether free will exists at all. Necessity can mean a lot of things in this context, but there are two meanings I would like to focus on. The first is apparent, non-absolute necessity. For example, if someone holds a gun to my head and tells me to do something, it’s necessary that I comply with their demand. Yes, theoretically I could disobey, but it would not be unreasonable for me to defend my actions later by saying “I had no choice!” I mention this kind of necessity first because it is the sort that actually affects people on a day-to-day basis (though hopefully in less extreme forms than my example). This kind of obvious and binding necessity, or the lack thereof, is the sort that affects the morality of actions, and determines how “free” people feel. The second is theoretical necessity. If an effect is entirely the result of its causes, then it was necessary in this sense of the word. One does not have to know what the causes were, only to know that they exist. One typically thinks of causes as deterministic, that is, if causes A and B occur, then effect C occurs with 100% certainty. But since we are speaking of necessity in the context of what free will is not, we can include randomness in our understanding of causality, because random acts are not thought of as being “chosen”. Also, probabilism, which is what you get when you mix determinism with randomness (for example, if causes A and B occur, then there is a 75% C will happen and a 25% chance D will happen), can also be included, for the same reason that weighted dice are not considered free agents. Free will, when discussed on an intellectual level, tends to be that which lies outside the domain of what I have described as theoretical necessity. Free Will, in this form, not only does not exist, but is self-contradictory to the point of meaninglessness—it could not possibly exist, even in principle. When people speak more generally (and less precisely) about “freedom” and “choice”, they tend to be referring to some form of the kind that is opposed to the apparent, non-absolute necessity I described earlier. This kind of freedom absolutely exists. This distinction between different meanings of necessity seems to be the basis of compatibilism and, more importantly, the conflation of the two meanings is I suspect the reason why people get so defensive when faced with the prospect of “free will” not existing, as the obvious and rather boring truism that effects have causes—deterministic, random, or probabilistic—gets morphed into the feeling that the laws of physics have put a gun to one’s head and are demanding obedience.

Free will? I think that's something to do with being able to make decisions disregarding any outside influence, i.e., you can eat a green apple not because it's the only apple there or that it's green, but rather because you want to for the sake of wanting to and without much of any other reason. Free will in itself doesn't make much sense, but I think we all know what it is. Perhaps the difficulty lies with articulation. Maybe it's just my own inability, but that's irrelevant. Now that I've at least somewhat given my own personal definition to it, let me divulge into the logic and possibility of it. I believe most of what we see as free will is a lack of understanding our own minds, how they work, and having a lack of skepticism in our actions for more or less narcissistic reasons. Why do you do what you do? Why do you act in some ways instead of others? Why are you reading this? Well, I think I can answer the third for you. Curiousity, right? Maybe it's just because you're bored? But then again, why specifically this? Probably a combination of the two. More likely because of a whole bunch of outside influence that neither you or I can name off of the top of our heads. To list the major ones tho, I'd say nature and nurture. For those of you who are unfamiliar with the nature v. nurture argument, it essentially entails how our personalities came to be. Nature being genes, genetics, chromosomes, etc. Nurture being our environment, how we were raised, our friends, etc. Personally, I think it's a combination of the two that makes us who we are. But what does all of that have to do with free will? It has everything to do with it. It is it. They are equal. Free will in the end is the miscomprehendtion of these two arguments. You didn't really eat that apple because you just wanted to. You ate it because you were hungry and it was most accessible at the time, or that you were just in the mood for an apple for one reason or another. You never do anything without a reason to do it. That reason either being genes or you're environment. Free will is just simply logically impossible. Not to bash anyone too much, but you know what group of people cite this “free will”most often? Christians. They do it as a way of blaming you for your own actions. It's a lie. Everything you do is not because you chose to. You have no control over anything you do. For example, a murderer isn't sent to jail, or rather shouldn't be anyways, because he “chose” to kill that person. Instead, he is sent there so he can't do it again. You can't blame people for what they do because they didn't actually have control over it. The other thing is that most people might look at this and think “well sure, I make my decisions based on what I can gain from them, but I still have the physical ability to do other things”. Thats true, you do have the physical ability to do other things. But guess what? You never will do those things because it would go against your very nature. So again, you can but you just never will. If you killed a person, you were going to no matter what, not including future possibilities. If you dont, you never would, at least in that specific case. I know that sounds like a really convenient argument, but that really is how it works. In my opinion, true and absolute free will would be totally and completely “random”, or at least unpredictable, and thusly, logically impossible. In the end, our free will really is just the illusion of choice. Nothing else.

God's the one with free will issues, not us. Being omniscient "screws the pooch" where free will’s concerned. Think about this: You can pick up a pen and drop it at any time. But the question is WILL you? Then as yourself: Why will you drop a pen?  In order to drop the pen, you have to want to prove you can drop a pen more than you want to conserve the energy required to pick up the pen. Why do you jump when somebody scares you?  Your fight or flight response is activated and your adrenaline spikes. In that moment, your reflexes detected a possible threat, which caused you to jump. In that moment, without realising it, because of your learned beliefs combined with your animal instincts, you unconsciously wanted to avoid a potential threat more than you wanted to risk being victim to it. Why does a smoker quit smoking?  Smoking is incredibly addictive due to the nicotine it puts into your bloodstream. In order for a smoker to quit smoking and unlearn the positive feedback loops created by the drug and the brain’s subconscious reaction to it, they have to want to stop smoking more than they want to smoke. They have to want to live longer and have improved mental health more than they want the short-term gratification of the cig. Why does a person leave a cult?  People leave cults often because they realise their cult wasn’t achieving what they thought it was. The perceived end result and the fantasy they lived in was no longer more desirable than the effort they put into supporting the cult. They no longer wanted what they thought the cult ultimately did more than they wanted the devotion and self-sacrifice that went into it. Now think about why a person does a selfless act:  In order for them to commit the act, they have to want the perceived end result more than they want alternatives and the price they put into it. In the moment that the act is committed, they have to have the perceived cause within their set of interests. Selfless people have the wants and/or needs of the many in their own interests. People who donate to charity have, in some small way, the interests of the people they think they are helping, whether it is true or false. People are the products of past stimuli. Every thought you have, no matter how creative, was derived from stimuli in some way. Trace every belief, no matter how rational or irrational, back and it will be caused by nature or evolution in some way. We receive stimulation from sights, sounds, other ideas from other people, ideas we make for ourselves- they are all derived from past stimuli. We like different colours because we learned to associate them with different ideas. If you choose to see it from another perspective, you can only choose to do that because you have learned that doing so might be a good idea. You have learned to feel rewarded by it. You can choose to try and improve yourself, but that requires a motivation- a first “knock” that gives you an idea. If you motivate yourself to do something, it’s only because you have learned in the past to be able to motivate yourself. If you choose to learn things now, it’s only because you have learned that learning is good. No. Free will does not exist. No matter what happens, every second of every day, and every action or thought, no matter how good or terrible, rational or irrational, good or bad, you are a slave to your own wants and past stimuli. Everything human is ironically a product of evolution. In order to do anything, you have to WANT to do something more than you want to not do it at the moment you choose to do it.

As Greg Klebanoff wrote, "You have asked one of the most important and profound of all philosophical questions." Society cannot survive unless it establishes rules with the expectation that because of the fear of punishment and the hope for reward the individual will make the choice to follow them. Everything in the physical world is determined by a succession of causes and their effects. Determinists point to fMRI studies demonstrating that a behavior is always initiated before one becomes aware of it, if at all, and therefore consciously asserting one’s will cannot be possible. If the power of one’s will could change causality, determination could not consistently exist. The concept of Compatibilism, that though we are in a determined universe free will also exists, championed by the ancient stoics and medieval scholastics such as Thomas Aquinas is rejected by both Determinists and believers in free will as a feeble excuse to avoid the attempt to resolve the issue. However, one answer to the philosophical question what is time may make Compatibilism possible. Many regard time as including past, present and future; events occurred in the past, occur in the present and will occur in the future. Existence of events in the physical reality, however, is limited to those occurring now. Those that had occurred or may occur exist in a mental reality as recollections or envisioned possibilities. The majority of the brain is dedicated to non-conscious functions. Behavior is unconsciously initiated by experiences arising from stimuli from the external and internal physical environment coupled with the experiences of conscious memory and imagination. Reflecting upon the consequences of prior actions and visualizing alternatives with the potential for more desirable results, one may alter their unconscious choices in the future. Free will exists within one’s mental reality.

We don't know yet. All of science is a way of making sense of things. As long as a theory makes logical sense and has thus far remained un-disproven, it is fair to accept it as a sufficiently accurate representation of reality.  By wrongly assuming that theories that seem to hold true at the moment will always hold true, we would be supporting a deterministic view of the universe. By saying that our understanding of the universe is absolute and that it isn't just one of the many ways reality can be more clearly perceived, we are saying that the universe is indeed, governed by a set of knowable rules, and that we have found some of those rules. Anything we can't explain, and as a result not predict or determine, scientists attribute to the gaps in our knowledge, and mystics attribute to an unknowable force that controls the universe. This unknowable force, that acts on it's own and is influenced by nothing else, is a superset of what you call Free Will, the possibility of a priori. The idea that not everything is cause and effect, and that something needs to have started it all. One way to understand this is to attribute this to divinity, and to say that God created the Universe. The more rational response would be to acknowledge that we don't really know yet. You can never know that a particular theory is absolute truth, because you can never know what new contradictory evidence we might discover tomorrow. Similarly, you can never know (with absolute certainty) that the universe is deterministic, because we will possibly never reach a state where we have found everything there is to be found and are able to define rules that explain all of them. A lot of important technology of today works on probabilistic models rather than on robust deterministic systems. Communication Technology is one example. The pursuit of knowledge is just that. A pursuit. It's like striving for perfection. You try to get as close as you can, and that ensures quality in your work, but you can't really ever expect to get there.  Whether free will exists or not is something we can not yet say with certainty, but what you can say, is that belief in the existence of free will is a necessary tool for human progress, and for enabling human morality. Centuries ago, people had built whole schools of thought around ideas that have been disproven since then. Knowledge is not absolute. What is important is the accuracy of these ideas within the scope of their application. When they were believed, the ideas were a sufficient representation of reality. They worked, and they were accepted. Free will, (like God), may or may not exist, but the idea of free will, (like the idea of god, for some people) is foundational to the functioning of the modern world.

1. Except on pains of insanity, it is impossible not to think of ourselves as free. Too many of our practices and beliefs presuppose a basic and important difference between acting freely and not acting freely. It is written in the details of our moral and legal discourse, and, even more fundamentally, it is implied in our everyday psychological self-awareness. Thoroughly integrated into one’s belief systems, the denial of free will would create a double-bind strong enough to drive one insane, for it would institute a rift between how one thinks about human action and how one must think of oneself and others if one is to function normally as a human being. For me to believe, for example, that the composition of this text — my choosing of these words rather than some others — is itself a fact explainable by factors beyond my control would effectively make my writing of them absurd, would indeed undermine the very conception of myself essential to continuing with this act. (It is no accident that the sense of having ones actions controlled by forces beyond oneself is a common delusion of schizophrenics.) One simply cannot see oneself as a marionette and go on with life as normal. To stop believing in our capacity for free will is, in essence, to stop believing in ourselves.  2. What makes belief in free will a problem is that none of the extant conceptions of free will holds water. The most straightforward and natural way to think of it is as the ability for one to act or not to act with respect to some option, and for that ability itself to be free from any necessitation. Taken together, these conditions describe exactly what acting freely feels like: I can do this or that, and nothing outside myself makes me do one or the other. On this view, the crucial matter for determining whether an action is free is what explains why one did this rather than that. The answer to that question cannot appeal to anything that is not also ultimately under the person’s control: one must be free all the way down. Importantly, there can be no final explanation of why one did this rather than that other than to say simply that one did it. Any further explanation would presumably appeal to something not under the agent’s control, and that just won’t do. But this creates a problem. The only acceptable explanation, according to this straightforward and natural way of thinking of free will, is not really an explanation at all. It does not in fact tell us why one did this rather than that. To say that an action is entirely unexplainable in this way is like saying that it is random. If there are no further factors making it more or less likely that one outcome or the other would result, then from the outside observer’s view, it is effectively like a toss of the dice. But whatever we might mean by freedom, we certainly do not mean anything like that. As with an action that is necessitated, this type of free action seems to be something not properly under the agent’s control. The free actions we care about are not random or in any way arbitrary but presumably directly related to the nature of the person in question. That’s what it means to say that they did it. So, this very natural understanding of free will seems to require something impossible: the ability to choose in a way that is both meaningfully tied to one’s nature and yet which is also open-ended at the most basic level. Human freedom, thus conceived, requires both roots deep in the earth and the gift of flight, a grounding in nature and an absolute freedom from constraint. It presumes us to be, at our motivational core, much like flying trees, and, like flying trees, an impossibility. 3. In light of the apparent failure of the intuitive conception of freedom, many philosophers — called “Compatibilists” because they think free will is logically compatible with necessitation — try to explain freedom in a way that doesn’t require such open-endedness. They say that freedom is just a matter of doing what one wants, or decides, or wills — or any other number of theories that interpret freedom as being something that is primarily psychological in nature and which does not entail the metaphysical indeterminacy that the first concept of freedom implies. Sometimes they jazz this up to give it the appearance of open-endedness, saying things like “instead of doing this, one could have done that, if one had so willed,” but of course this just pushes the problem back to the new condition. One wants to ask: okay, so could one have so willed? And so on. At any rate, none of the Compatibilist theories work, for it can always be shown that the seat of a person’s freewill so-called — their desire, decision, will, etc. — is dissoluble in the larger nexus of causes, and therefore explainable in terms of factors not under their control. In other words, all such factors can be shown to be the consequences of factors that are beyond the agent’s control. (This point was made with ruthless logical clarity in Peter Van Inwagen’s An Essay on Free Will.) The Compatibilist conception of freedom is too superficial, too subjective in nature, a matter of appearance rather than reality. At best, it provides an account of the persistence of the illusion of freedom. This is fine as an explanation of how the naive may proceed, but it poses a terrible problem for the Compatibilist philosopher. The philosopher understands that what seems true to him and other human beings — that one is ultimately in control of whether one does this or that — is actually not true. That is a remarkable admission, and it would take the cleverness, self-deceptive skill, and overall jadedness (“metaphysical insouciance,” as I once heard a prominent Compatibilist philosopher describe it) of a hardened academic to avoid feeling the gravity of it. 4. To summarize: On the one hand, free will can be interpreted as a sort of detachment from the world of causes and effects that allows maximum movement but precludes meaningful engagement. It makes free will effectively random. On the other hand, free will can be defined in a largely subjective way, an illusion of autonomy entirely consistent with absorption in the world of causes and effects, an ersatz “freedom” that precludes truly spontaneous and sovereign action. So, either we are alienated from the causal order of the world or we are absorbed by it. Any way you slice it, we get nothing adequate to our lived experience of freedom, nothing that makes sense of what we must assume, on pains of insanity, about ourselves. The problem of free will is one of the most persistent, complex, and confusing problems in the history of philosophy. Its solution, if one should be forthcoming, will only be found in a very deep re-conceptualization of the causal order of things as well as of ourselves. Or it could be that in this venerable puzzle of philosophy, indeed in the very fact of free will, one faces what is rightly called a mystery: something now and forever beyond our intellectual ken. This last option will undoubtedly make some of us descendants of the Enlightenment very uncomfortable. But wouldn’t it be surprising if there were no such things in life? What leads us to think that human intelligence, evolved for the purposes of survival and reproduction, should be adequate to comprehend all manner of things? And if there were a place where human understanding runs up against its limits, wouldn’t the nature of free will be an ideal candidate?

Scientifically, most likely no, free will as we understand it, does not seem to exist. This is somewhat like Stephen Hawkings’ statement of God, we do not see scientifically how or where can it exist. Philosophically and politically though, it has a very important implication — can we deny (or replace) free will with any more scientifically accurate or verifiable definition or description? No. Which means free will, although we somewhat know does not exist literally, is still (one of) the best metaphors for something that we can’t describe better - the individual cognitive identity - how we cognitively differentiate one individual from another? We may one day find a better, more accurate description of it, but before that, free will is our best effort in trying to allow individual minds to process information with minimum external manipulation. Philosophically, this also means equality — with free mind, comes the freedom of pursuing things each individual wants, and responsibility associated with it. Before we go down the path of having “ME” determine what each one of your mind is thinking, and distribute resources accordingly, there might be a debate about why “MY” mind is allowed to determine everyone of yours thoughts? Before we can find a scientific reason, free will is our best tool to restrain our own urge of intervene in other people’s thoughts (hence ensure some level of equality in the society).

response.answer_text: Not only is there room for free will in a deterministic universe, free will is an essential component for surviving and evolving in one. It is an essential component of consciousness, which is an essential component of life. Free will is a feeling that we all experience. There is no denying of experience. There is only deciphering the nature of it. Free will is not the illusion. In its conflict with determinism lies the illusion. Free will is the product of not knowing, and of the unknowable. Both are plausible and frequent even in a deterministic universe. Nothing has to be random. There just has to be unknowns. At this point whether the universe is deterministic becomes trivial because it does not help any immediate cause for any subject indulging in its free will. The conflict between determinism and free will evaporate when knowledge and circumstances are placed in any naturally occurring order. The conflict of free will only occurs when this order is tampered with or ignored, as many thought experiments do. The illusion of free will is inherited from the illusion of these experiments. With proper experiments, we can obtain concrete free will even within a deterministic universe, as with the following example from Ron Maimon:  For example, let's take "free will". Looks like a difficult question, doesn't it? So let's define free will in terms of sense impressions. I notice I can move my hand. Big deal. Ok, there are atoms and let's say they are deterministic. Does this contradict me moving my hand? No. But if someone knows all the position, he can tell me whether I will move my hand or not without consulting me. Doesn't this contradict free will? No more than me saying "Jack Nicholson is going to get out of bed tommorrow." It's true, but that doesn't mean Jack Nicholson is being manipulated by me, or somehow "isn't free". The issue is that it seems I don't have any choice in lifting my hand. But how would you demonstrate this to me? You could come in and say "computer calculated your hand, and said you are going to lift it ... now!" But then, by talking to me, you are shaking air atoms, thereby ruining the computer's prediction. When I head what you say, I keep my hand down and say "sorry, computer was wrong." So you can spite any prediction when you know about it, and this is consistent with atoms behaving deterministically, and if you don't know about the prediction, it's not much of a challenge to your free will. So the free will question is solved, there is no question, it's just an illusion in the mind that there ever was a conflict between free will and determinism, people were just stupid. What Ron illustrates is the inherent positivism in nature and in our existence (the above is an excerpt from his answer: Ron Maimon's answer to What is logical positivism? What are some of the inherent flaws within its schema?). With positivism, there are no contradictions. To add, consider what randomness is. Randomness emerges when we lack information. Random = Unable to predict. This happens easily with a lack of information, and if there is anything we lack, it is information. Free will is the experience of being faced with decisions and being provided with options. To this end, you must be something that needs to make decisions to experience it. The weather does not experience free will. We can feel it because we cannot predict what anything alive will do in the next moment. We cannot even predict our own actions for the most part. But this feeling of not knowing and the world being unpredictable is what is important! What would you do without it? What would you do if "what would you do" was never a choice? Nature has answered this question for us, and free will is its answer.  Free will gave the universe life, and it is, without question, why we feel alive. Do you feel alive? Free will is the solution to not knowing. It's nature's way of compensating for our inability to predict our actions and the actions of others. Questions regarding determinism are always framed with the premise that we know everything. We are free to keep hoping this will one day become possible, but even in a world where it is, there will be plenty of people and circumstances in which this information will not be available. One such circumstance is how we view and experience the world as living human beings. The premise of our existence is lack of information. We are biologically designed to obtain information and figure out how to survive, given our lack of initial information. What are senses? What is our brain? What is our body for? We are a machine designed to cope with the unknown, to gather knowledge, and to work within the boundaries of our existence with the goal to survive. So to put ourselves in a situation where the premise is we know absolutely everything is a leap of epic proportions. We would break before it made sense. If anything, it would be impossible to be deterministic and human at the same time. And herein specifically lies the conflict, and the illusion. Finally, the above interpretation of free will fits nicely with the computational universe paradigm also. A program cannot predict the outcome of its own execution without actually executing its code. The code is determined, and the outcome is also. However, the outcome cannot be obtained without execution, which is never free. Execution costs energy and time. The problem isn't whether any outcome is predetermined or not. The problem is whether we can predict its outcome without paying for execution. And here we have room for free will.  Free will isn't a force that contradicts determinism. It is a force that complements it, in circumstances where execution must precede outcome. Free will is a program guessing what could happen if resources were spent executing code before having to execute it. A program can only execute its own code. The same applies for humans. We can only execute our own code. The next leap in our understanding of ourselves will be in the deciphering of this code, which is completely obtainable. We are open source, and all we need are the tools to read our code. However, even then, the outcome of that code will not be obtainable until it is executed. And this is precisely why we will always have room for free will. And if free will is a must, we can work backwards and see that actually we do not need to know everything once we have free will. We don't even need to know or understand our code. Free will makes up for all of it, and rewards us with a sense of freedom and being alive. That makes free will an amazing piece of code, if it is in fact a program, which it would be under the terms of the computational universe.

Yes, we really have free will. Please let me offer some definitions: By “free will”, I mean one’s ability to cause things that one likes and to prevent things that one dislikes. By “really”, I mean that such ability exists to some degree. There is not a total absence of such ability. By “we” — and this is the crux of the whole explanation — I mean a complex entity with two main aspects. (1) We are part of a fabric of causes-and-effects. We arise from causes that produce us as effects, and in turn we are causes that produce effects. (2) We are sentient. We experience phenomena. We make some sense of our experience with our intelligence. We suffer and enjoy. Now, the degree to which we have free will is the degree to which those two aspects overlap. If there is little overlap, if the events we experience have little to do with the events we cause, then we have little free will. We suffer the kind of world that Emerson described: “Events are in the saddle, and ride mankind.” In contrast, if there is much overlap, if we cause the events that we suffer and enjoy, then we have much free will. Certainly, behavior and subjective experience have a physical basis in the chemistry and biology of the brain. However, that does not answer the question of whether we have free will. Rather, it identifies a place to investigate the question. As a crude simile, we can say that the neural signals in the brain are like billiard balls colliding and careening in ways conditioned by physical laws. An obvious next question is: What were the preceding events that kicked off those movements? At the billiards table, there are moments of intention, when a player aims and strokes a cue stick. In the brain, why does the neural signalling follow certain patterns, and why do the patterns change? It seems to me that the brain has moments of intention, too, and that the intentions, themselves, have an impact on the brain. May I suggest a Zen story? 2. Hyakujo's Fox A student asked “whether or not the enlightened man is subject to the law of causation.” The answer had far-reaching consequences.

According to the wisdom of Kabbalah, we are chained not only by biological genes, but there is a program running through us, which we are parts of, not only in this lifetime, but throughout a long and consistent chain of Reshimot (“records” or “reminiscences”) that are embedded in the mind, the heart and the soul. This programming of Reshimot is what determines our lives. In this case, if we exist inside a program that has been predetermined, where is our freedom and independence? We can become free and independent to the extent that we rise about our nature, which is an egoistic desire (i.e. a desire to enjoy for self-benefit alone). Everything in nature, including our own human nature, is predetermined, and so in order to attain real and absolute freedom, we need to activate a special mechanism to open the door of the “cage” of our corporeal world, into a spiritual, eternal and free world. We can conclude from life experience and history that freedom is a concept that we strive toward and fight for. Our lives are full of struggles for bits of fictitious freedom that society presents us with. We try to be as it would have us be, and we are prepared to fill up our lives with empty acts, just to get some appreciation and respect. At first, we fight for freedom from the burdens of parents and the family. We try to escape circumstances that were forced on us, and the duties that make our lives difficult. We invest a great deal of effort just to attain this fake freedom. But in order to attain genuine freedom—freedom from our nature, where everything is predetermined—we have to apply efforts. Such freedom can be attained not in the afterlife, as religions promise us, but here in the corporeal world, in this very life. However, in order to realize this freedom, we need to put in efforts to rise above our nature, above our world. What does “above our world” mean? It means that we acquire spiritual attributes, beyond the five senses (sight, smell, touch, hearing, taste) that we perceive our world with. How, then, is it possible to rise above our world and acquire the spiritual attributes? It is possible through the choice of an environment that guides such progress. Parents change their location, or change an address on their ID in order to select the place where their children will learn by themselves, and the kind of education that they want for them. They try and create for their children such an environment that they believe will guarantee their positive development, and they are absolutely right in doing so. They naturally understand that when they are under the influence of a certain environment, there is no freedom of choice, and so they will try to act in the one place where they can make a difference, the freedom to choose the environment that would influence them. Many philosophers tried to analyze and measure the influence of the environment on people’s personalities. On the basis of research and experiments that were made, and also through their own intuition, they realized how powerful such influence was. The wisdom of Kabbalah provides a full analysis of the influence of the environment on us. Its conclusions are unequivocal: a person is completely dependent on his environment, willingly or unwillingly. It is thus important to understand how to build such an environment, and what we need it for.

Few notes / supplements to previous answers: 1. Like Shan Kothari noted, Whether free will exists or not depends on the definition. If to act freely means to act without coercion or compulsion, and that the person is the source of the action, then free will is quite easy to demonstrate. If, however, by free will you mean a deeper kind of self autonomy then it might be more difficult to demonstrate. Another thing is our concept of the "I" who acts freely, that might influence our answer to the question. 2. Quantum Mechanics does not strictly contradict determinism. It depends on interpretation. 3. Indeterminism does not necessarily mean that free will exists. Some problems remain. For example, the problem of differentiating humans and sunflowers with regards to free will and autonomy: If events in the world are determined only probabilistically, both the sunflower's angle of turning towards the sun and human action are probabilistic in nature, or not fully determined. So whats to make the human action free and the sunflower action not free? We would need some kind of mechanism or "deus ex machina" that will enable us to be the ones who choose between the different probabilities. Furthermore, if the world is random and not even probabilistic, free will is even less probable because in that case our actions would be hardly different than a coin toss. 4. There are philosophers who claim that free will cannot exist whether the world is deterministic or not, because the idea itself is impossible. One of them is Galen Strawson who proposes this argument to support this view (in terms of moral responsibility):(a) In order to be morally responsible, one has to be the cause of one's action.(b) but we act because of the way we are and, (c) we are not the cause of the way we are, or, in other words - one does not control the way he is. (d) You might say that some people can control or cause the way they are, but (e) even if this is true, they could only control the way they are in virtue of the way they were previously to that. (f) And if they could choose the way they were previously, it could have only been done in virtue of the way they were before that. (g) And so on, in an infinite regress. When you think about it goes eventually to one's childhood or infancy, times where one can obviously not choose the way he is. (h) Hence free will (in the broad, libertarian sense) and moral responsibility are not possible.(This argument appears in: Galen Strawson,The Impossibility of Moral Responsibility, 1993. If there is interest, I can post a more detailed version of it).

I will refer to some of the key arguments mentioned by others. I will be very happy to discuss this topic further. Also, thank you for the great input. Shan Kothari (SK) says, "It is possible, but hard to see how."  1. SK, "If the universe is deterministic, then we obviously don't have free will, because we can't have chosen otherwise."  The universe could be deterministic, but that would not imply that we don't have a free will. The history of the universe (the so-called "past" and "future") could be written in the Book and we could be given the responsibility to influence the system (for some disguised reasons given how limited we are), i.e. make decisions, but - for some deeper reasons - our decisions could always be the same ones as those in the Book.  2. SK, "If the universe is not deterministic, then it is random. If our decisions are random, they're not freely willed." If a link between two elements of a chain does not exist for us (someone),  it just leaves (from our perspective) an empty space that is "somehow" filled, not randomness. Randomness means that this empty space could be filled with all possible values with the same probability and we use it for modeling purposes (since it may explain variance behind the data quite well). Just because something does not exist for me or you, it may exist for some other reference frames. Hence, determinism and randomness do not necessarily exhaust all possibilities.  Glyn Williams (GW), "We are, for want of a better description, engines that make decisions. So it's not surprising we take responsibility for those decisions. This ownership over our own actions creates the illusion of free will. And very satisfying it is too. But all our choices, deeds and actions are the result of some prior causes: Memories, genetic-predispositions, character defects, accidents, lusts, goals - momentary neurochemical flickerings or just random quantum interactions.  In other words, just atoms doing physics.  No will. No freedom." Indeed, all actions need to be considered together with the rest of the universe (the Monty Hall problem and books on machine learning teach you about priors). Still, decisions could not be "ours" in first place given what we think about us as humans (we are built out of particles, have creatures inside us, understand very little about our brains, what makes decisions?).  We would need to define what identity is and accept that we cannot be considered without our history (and likely our future, too). So, the fact that our decisions depend on some prior causes does not necessarily imply that free will does not exist.  SK, "In short, we don't really know whether free will does or does not exist. It's premature to go either way." I agree. Machines are gonna help us with the learning :)

There are two ways to answer this:1. The universe may be deterministic, but it is so computationally difficult to predict what a human might do that the only way to determine this is by simulating the human. Then we have in effect free will because we cannot in any meaningful sense predict what a human can do. We can only watch and observe what they (or an simulation of this human) can do. 2. The currently accepted definition of free will is wrong. I personally do not believe in the concept of free will as an absolute. I believe that free will is relative to an observer. For example, an omniscience god would look at a human and conclude a human has no free will because the omniscience god knows everything, including what they will do. On the other hand, a human would not consider a mouse to have have free will because we can put the mouse in a particular situation and predict what they will do. In the middle is a human observing a second human. Since they cannot predict what the human will do, the other human has free will as seen form a human observer. If you think of free will as a relative quality, not absolute, then all us humans have free will as seen from the position of our fellow humans.

The original question is: Does free will exist? Answer: Both the determinism and free-will co-exist. “Life is like a game of cards. The hand you're dealt, is determinism; the way you play it, is free-will” Your personality, physical and mental, you are born with, and the environment, your familial, cultural and financial, you are born into, make up your fate. This is your initial deposit in the account of your life. A person is defined by the choices he makes on a day-to-day basis and by the actions he takes in response to the stimuli of the world around him. Essentially, an individual is determined by the degree to which he exercises his own free-will. The great philosopher-poet Sri Aurobindo has a beautiful phrase for the present moment: the pure and virgin moment---that razor’s edge of time and existence which divides the past from the future. The present is yet unlived and unspoilt, and therefore, is very much changeable. Where there is a will, there is a way. Here your free-will comes in. You can change the present the way you want, and consequently, the future too, for the future is the outcome of the present. Positive thinking has an effective role to play. It has been proved that most of us have been living far below our potential. We have to analyze and assess our merits and demerits, without bias and with a clinical precision. Then we have to start developing by making optimal utility of our merits. If we move ahead with a passion and determination, none can stop us except our own negativity and habitual lethargy. Lots of folks mistake their bad management of life for destiny. But positive thinking has its own limits which our motivational speakers don’t concede, at least in public. Now-a-days, their stereotypes are ubiquitous and they keep dishing out, day in and day out, their worn-out fables, parables and platitudes. As Schopenhauer says, ‘A man can do what he will, but not will as he will.’ Imagine a hen tied to a post with a metre-length rope. The hen is no doubt is bound and its freedom of movement is apparently curtailed. All the same, it can move as freely as it wants within the circle described by the radius of a metre. If it rues that it is fettered and becomes disheartened that it cannot move, it forgoes its freedom of movement even within that circle. Positive thinking and motivation help it to make maximum utility of the available freedom of movement. But no amount of inspirational talk can make it get beyond the circle. We can create our own destiny and enjoy living to the limits of our potential. Each of us is unique. It has been found that the average person only employs a small per cent of his latent abilities. He has various physical and mental resources which he habitually fails to use. You and I have such resources. Evaluate your strengths and weaknesses. Then, start building on your strengths and discover how many talents and abilities you have that you didn’t even imagine you had. If once we begin putting them to optimum use, we will be changing our otherwise statuesque fate and fulfilling our possible destiny with an informed free-will, and that too, with a vengeance! This is the miracle of life, this celebration—living and enjoying the good life to the limits of one’s IQ and EQ!

If I supposedly have free will, I'll opt to not have free will. If I must have free will, then I don’t have free will.
