I’ve always had a deep interest in neuroscience, and some of the work of Numenta: Home of the HTM Community, especially their The Thousand Brains Theory of Intelligence shines a lot of light on this question. To properly approach an answer to this question, one must learn some neuroscience. There is no way around it. It is no different from needing to know Differential Geometry to understand and appreciate General Relativity, as Einstein discovered long ago.  The above is taken from the above references. In this illustration, you are seeing (!) how you may recognize a cup. You can see the cup with your eyes; you may touch the cup with your fingers. In both cases. you perceive the cup, and even with your eyes closed, you would still recognize the cup. This is all going on in your cortical columns, as illustrated below:  Basically, as the thousand brains theory goes, each of your cortical columns possess the model for “cup”, and many other objects you are familiar with. Based on the tactile input from your fingers, the cortical columns associated with each finger gets part of the input, which might match many different objects in the single column. But what happens is that all the cortical columns, one for each finger tip, etc., all vote on what they think the object is, and your conscious mind only become aware of the outcome of the voting process. Hence, you perceive “cup”. The same is true when your eye scans the field. It’s the same process, really. There are deeper issues going on with these cortical columns, and I entreat you to follow my links above, or at least watch this:  Jeff Hawkins is the founder of Numenta, which is doing something novel in the research of AI: studying the brain to see how it does things, and then understanding ways to replicate that in code. So here, neuroscience meets AI. Now, what does all this say about “free will”? Jeff does not approach that question in his research directly. I would love to hear his views on it, however. Here’s my take on it: “Free will” is a construct our neocortex creates. Well, there’s more to it than that. You see, there is the concept of “free will”, and the actual supposed manifestations of “free will”. I don’t think one can even approach “free will” without also approaching the question of consciousness itself. And I will have to say that even our consciousness and self-awareness are constructs. Our neocortex monitors itself, as it does sensory input from the outside world, and those cortical columns are also involved with the modelling of both. Both are useful fictions that basically serves as model of interaction with the complex world we live in. They allow us to move, navigate, and interact with the world in complex ways. They allow for abstractions and inference. They allow for our brains to create novelty that would allow us to devise strategies for survival that evolution alone would be far too slow to adapt to. Our qualia are all useful fictions. For example, the colours that you see every day, or music your ears experience, are all constructs. The colour “red” does not exist in nature anymore than the music of Mozart. They are what our neocortex represent them as to our conscious minds, itself a product of representation. This conclusion will be profoundly disturbing to some, perhaps to most. It is something I personally feared to be the case for decades, and now our new level of understanding of neuroscience appears to confirm it. So, in conclusion, free will, consciousness, self awareness, etc., are all useful fictions to allow us to circumnavigate life itself.  What are the implications of this? Should the above conclusions affect how we interact with one another? Should it affect the nature of jurisprudence? Does it change the “love” we feel for those that are “close” to us? I would say, no. It is one thing to take the “red pill”, as it were. It’s quite another thing to know what to do about it, if anything is to be done about it at all. And what can you do, really? if a perpetrator harms you or someone you care about, you are not going to be interested in “the devil made me do it” style of excuses, now are you? Nope. You’ll want justice to be properly served on the perpetrator, regardless of whether “free will” is merely a construct or not. Just count it as a deep and terrible secret you know about human existence. If anything, you should appreciate the “mystery” of our existence even more, and at a deeper level than ever before.  On the theological front, I will state that I am an Atheist, big time. However, why so many wish to entertain the notions of deities is a rather complex topic. And worthy of a discussion on a separate topic / question in its own right.

No.  Or, rather, there's no reason to believe it exists other than "it sure feels like it." If that's reason enough for you, then so be it. I think feelings are really profound aspects of being human, but they're not good predictors of reality, of facts about the physical universe.   Let's talk about the moment leading up to when I choose between a vanilla and chocolate ice-cream cone. The causes of that moment started with the Big Bang. The Big Bang caused THIS which cause THAT which cause SOMETHING ELSE, and so on. And, eventually, we get atoms forming into a planet with people and ice-cream cones on it. And brains. And brains that have a preference for certain flavors.   We also have situations, like the fact that the grocery store ONLY had vanilla for the past month, and I'm really, really tired of it. And we have the fact that my father, who beat me when I was little (not really), loved vanilla ice cream.    We have all these genetic and upbringing-based and situational pressures that lead me to choose chocolate.   Now, almost everyone I've met who believes in free will doesn't dispute any of that. They say, "Yes, we're not TOTALLY free. We have all these pressures that come from our genes and our upbringing and whatnot... But in the END, we STILL have the freedom to choose. Maybe some times we lose our will and give into temptations or whatever. But a lot of the time, we are free to choose." What does that mean, exactly? Who is the "we" that is choosing?  Let's imagine a brain. Not a real brain but a cartoon one. A simple, simple model of a human brain: it has a makes-choices-based-on-genes region. That takes up, say, 20% of the brain. It has a makes-choices-based-on-upbringing region. That takes up 30%. To please the quantum physicists, let's say it has a region that makes-choices-based-on-randomness. That takes up 20%. Then there's the region that is makes-choices-determined-by-what's-happening-right-now and what-just-happened. That's another 20%. All those parts weigh in saying "chocolate! chocolate! chocolate!"  But that final 10%, the free-me part, says, "NO! I VETO THAT! VANILLA!" Okay, that was silly, The brain isn't really like that. There's no a determined-by-genes part that separate from a determined-by-nurture part. The whole brain is shaped by many forces, including genetics and environmental ones. But if the free-willers are right, there's still some part of the brain that is free. It can overrule all the other forces. When genes and upbringing and randomness say "no," it can say "yes." (If that's not true, in what sense do we have FREEDOM of will? If we're TOTALLY constrained by genes and so on, how are we free? You can't be totally constrained and free at the same time.)   So that free bit... What is it? Where is it? What's your evidence for it existing, other than, as I said at the start, "it feels like it exists"? (If you believe free will exists because you feel like it does, that's fine, but be honest about it. Say, "I have no evidence for it. I just feel like it exists.")   That free bit, which is not controlled by genes or upbringing or situation or randomness, is cut off from the causal chain going back to the Big Bang. How did that happen? Are OTHER things cut off from that chain? Is it possible that, tomorrow, I'll push a bowling ball down a hill and it will roll upwards, because it is free from normal causation?   And if that part of me is not making its choices based on genes or whatnot, what IS it making its choices based on? "Whatever it wants?" How does it get those wants? What causes them? Genes, upbringing, etc.? No. It can't be that! That's what the will is free from.    So you have a supernatural entity in your head, one that can't be detected and one that you have no proof of? That's what free will is.

Two books that influenced my views on free will are "The User Illusion" by Tor Norretranders and "The Illusion Of Conscious Will" by Daniel Wegner.  Research shows that the human brain is designed to create the illusion of control even when that control is objectively absent (for example, believing you have control over a mouse pointer on a computer monitor, when in fact it is being controlled by someone else or by a program).  Wegner argues that the internal experience of will or voluntary action is best viewed as an emotion, what he calls an "authorship emotion".  The internal experience does not necessarily match objective reality. What this suggests is that even if we are completely deterministically driven beings, our brains are designed to convince us that we are free.  Presumably our brains evolved this way because the authorship emotion has survival value for humans. Many people believe they have control over their own thoughts, even if not over all their actions or any of their emotions.  But this belief is also easily disproved by experiment.  Pick any thought you would like to have, and decide to think only that and nothing else for 5 minutes.  OK, how about 1 minute?  All right, now try to exclude all thought from your mind for 2 minutes.  How about 30 seconds?  Students of meditation have been running these experiments for millennia, and the results are clear: thoughts arise and disappear through mechanical processes that are entirely outside of our control.  It is claimed that after years of training and conditioning, some of them do learn to focus exclusively on some thoughts and exclude other thoughts, but it is difficult to validate those claims objectively. Since most conceptions of free will involve a subject generating a thought (freely, voluntarily) and then carrying it through to an action, it is hard to argue that free will exists.

The original question was “What does it mean “free will does not exist?”” The idea is that determinism precludes free will. Determinism is the idea that every event is determined by, i.e. is the necessary result of, previous events. So that when you make a choice, whether impulsively or after long deliberation, that choice is entirely determined by the events leading up to it - the full circumstances, including your mental state. From a personal (subjective) viewpoint, we can and do make free choices - we can assess the circumstances, visualize the available options, imagine the likely outcome of each, and select the option that we want at the time; it seems to me that this is what most people mean by ‘exercising their free will’. But objectively, those deliberations are determined by the circumstances - how we perceive the circumstances, how we analyze the options, the cognitive abilities and experiences we bring to bear on them, how we feel about the outcomes at the time, etc. These are what determine our choices, and they are, in turn, determined by prior events. So the whole process, including what we wish to do (our ‘will’) is determined by what came before, which means there really isn’t any freedom involved. People often say they have free will because they could have chosen differently in some particular circumstances; but in a deterministic world, in order for them to have made a different choice, something would have had to be different, either in the circumstances, or in their mental state at the time. So they could have chosen differently if circumstances - or how they felt about those circumstances - had been different. Things (the choice) would have been different if things (circumstances) had been different… That’s a deterministic tautology. So in one - subjective - sense, we freely choose what we wish, and in another - objective - sense, what we wish is determined by prior events, so there aren’t really any choices. As Isaac Bashevis Singer said, “We must believe in free will — we have no choice.”

We are not free to choose what we are, we are only free to choose what we do. And we can only do what our muscles can do. On a deeper level free will means having a choice. This means that we are free from deterministic causation. We are not forced to do what causality by past events would dictate. We can follow our intentions, our desire for a certain kind of future instead. Our decisions are affected by past events. One might even say that our decisions are made by past events, because that is what we essentially are, individual collections of past events. The freedom is in having a choice of alternative actions to satisfy our will. In the core of free will is our ability to see and invent alternative courses of action. That requires some random thinking outside the box. In essence, free will is deterministic filtering of randomly generated ideas. It enables us to act spontaneously and creatively while still being true to what we are. Due to involving randomness, free will is incompatible with full determinism. In full determinism there could not be any randomness at all nor any illusion thereof. In fact, there could not be any illusions at all, as they would represent an alternative view of the reality and there simply are no alternatives in full determinism.

I've been thinking about this issue for quite a while now, and I think I've finally formed my opinion. I don't think it's accurate to say free will does or does not exist, as I think it's kind of a mixture of both, and that's not me just settling for middle-ground. Here is a piece I wrote on the topic: While the issue of choice and freedom is a familiar one in the eyes of the modern person, free will is not necessarily the most ancient of topics in existence. This is because for a creature to debate the existence of its free will, it must have reached a sufficient level of intelligence and self-awareness. This intimate realization of one’s own existence is a prerequisite to the capability to ponder the nature of said existence: is it a free one, or is it determined? Humans must have, therefore, reached a certain level of intelligence, before which we were incapable of comprehending what being free really is, and whether or not we are free agents. In here, I will be relating freedom to intelligence, demonstrating that at least some degree of freedom is an inevitable side-effect to attaining a high level of intellect. Often do determinists claim that consciousness is the source of the illusion of freedom. They go on to claim that our choices and actions have causal relationships with a variety of factors coming from our environment. The sheer quantity and diversity of these factors, be them psychological, or environmental, or whatever, makes tracking a cause or reason for an action not only impossible, but also downright incorrect (as there are in fact many interdependent reasons for a decision). While such reasoning is partly valid, it neglects internal factors that ultimately affect everything we do, and are perhaps just as important. What such reasoning neglects is the effect our own thoughts and analysis have on a situation; In other words, it neglects the extra factor that consciousness, and specifically self-awareness, brings to the table. This self-awareness cannot be brushed away as a mere metaphysical, nonexistent entity. It is inherently existent, and is in many ways tangible, not metaphysical. The fact that it is an established and recognized word proves that it is a real and essential part of the human experience, rooted in physical aspects of human physiology. Denying its existence is tantamount to denying happiness exists: just because something is part of a subjective experience, doesn’t mean it is not part of any objective reality (i.e whatever causes the sensation of happiness, or the state of self-awareness, is itself an existent entity in this universe). Now that we have established self-awareness as a real entity capable of affecting occurrences and outcomes, it is worthwhile to focus on how a creature’s own self-awareness affects the decisions it makes. If we prove that a person’s self-awareness, resulting from our relatively high level of intelligence, does affect the choices we make, then we have established solid ground for our existence as at least partially-free agents. Ultimately, what it comes down to is our intellect, which gives us analytical skills, as well as the capability to not only reflect on the current situation, but also make predictions as well as reflect back on previous decisions. When these mental processes occur in tandem with a state of awareness, a person attains the ability to express thought, and offer insight. The silent, inner ramblings that occur in each and every one of us, are in fact factors we react to. For example, thinking of a sad, even distant, memory can cause one to cry. Crying is an action occurring as a result of a stimulus delivered internally. Further, a deep analysis of the general situation leads an intelligent being to change their course of action. What such analysis, or distant memories intentionally brought into the present, or conscious mental processes in general, have in common is that they are rooted in thought; they are ultimately expressed or performed through a particular type of thought that is self-aware. Some may argue that even these thoughts aren’t quite “up to us”, but the very essence of freedom is whether we have an effect on the things we do, and our thoughts, which are expressions our conscious selves, are what we really, truly identify with. In other words, consciousness and who we are are very much the same two things. And since consciousness, as demonstrated previously, does affect the things we do, we do actually have a say, and are in a way, free agents. In conclusion, though a deterministic world-view may be factually accurate by reducing actions to a series of interactions between a living creature and a complex network of factors, determinism tends to completely neglect internal factors arising from our intelligence. It should be obvious that our conscious selves’ ability to, with their mere expression of thoughts, partially affect the decision-making process is at least a discrete form of freedom.

The question requires a useful definition of free will to begin with. I claim that such a definition should be relative (i.e. the free will of a system compared to that of another) rather than absolute, such that for each pair of systems we can define a measure of free will advantage of one over the other. My definition is as follows: A has more free will than B if A can simulate B, therefore predict and therefore control it. Of course the ability of A to predict and control is not binary, rather it is a spectrum whereon one end of it is total simulation of a system and ability to control all "inputs" to it, and on the other end - randomness - total non-understanding of a system. The key concept is this: What is random to us may be less random to higher systems. We have more free will than a rock, but (at least as individuals) we do not have more free will than the stock exchange. For further reading: The above answer closely relates to the concept of Kolmogorov complexity. And another note: I think this is also a good definition for intelligence.

Do we have freewill? What is “freewill”, or “free will”? What makes it “free”, and what makes it “will”? To my mind, anything that happens may be deterministic, in that it is in principle fully explicable in terms of physics;¹ e.g. you made decision X because, deep in your brain, neuron A fired off a chain reaction through networks B through K, releasing neurochemical L, …, &c.; at the end of which series of deterministic physical events, the result is that you perform some given action; ornon-deterministic, in the way that quantum mechanical events may be, which is to say unconstrained by anything exterior, except in setting up the probability distribution.Now, what do you mean by free will?  Is your will free if it is subject to deterministic physics? It may be free from any number of kinds of coercion, but it clearly isn't free from inevitable causality. Is it free if some  aspects of it is non-deterministic—which is to say, are utterly random, with no regard to your life experience, your thoughts, your preferences?  If so, it may (to some degree) be free from causality, but I've never  heard anyone say that by freedom, they mean the freedom to do things unintentionally, entirely at random.  Or do you mean some nebulous libertarian free-will notion, where you have some magic external control that is neither  deterministic nor non-deterministic? If so, I'd be fascinated (and I do mean this) to have a cogent explanation of what you mean.  If I had to answer this question with simply “yes” or “no”, I would say no—we don’t have free will, because it is not a coherently defined concept. That is, it’s not that “free will” describes a property that we lack, but rather that the common notion of “free will” fails to actually apply to any logically consistent reality. Of the logically coherent possibilities, it seems to me that determinism is preferable to non-determinism. (Which does not say anything about whether it’s true; but I do take exception with the common demonisation.) Ideally, I want my decisions to be based on my best understanding of reality, and move me toward the best course of action to further my goals in alignment with my ideals. But if I want to always make the best possible decision, that really does single out one possible decision for every choice; so that, whether determinism is true or not, I should hope that I act as though it were by always choosing the best option.  ¹ Or, if you’re a dualist, perhaps by some extra-physical mechanism of the ‘spirit’ or ‘soul’; but I don’t see how this frees you from logical constraints of causality. Note that when I speak of chain reactions and the “end” of a series, the salient relationship is causal dependency rather than temporal ordering. If you want to suppose some time-and-space-less spirit does your thinking, its thoughts still have causal antecedents…or not—but not something in between.

Yes A lot depends on how you define it. Generally speaking, when people talk about free will, they are referring to one of two very different ideas. Compatibalist free will is the idea that all that matters is that your choices feel meaningful and significant to you. It doesn’t matter if they’ve been predetermined or not, so long as they belong to you, rather than some outside agency. Free will thus becomes a question of outside influence. Was someone holding a gun to your head, forcing you to make a particular choice? Did someone have undue influence over you, fooling you into making a particular deicsion? If not, your choice was free. It’s generally accepted that we have at least this form of free will. Incompatibalist free will is the idea that all that matters is whether you could have made a different decision, whether your decisions are pre-determined. If they are, you don’t have free will. If you can decide otherwise, then they are. A lot of the people motivated to answer questions like this will tend to argue against this form of free will. It’s called incompatibalist, because it’s incompatible with a school of philosophical thought known as determinism. Determinism is the idea that all events in the universe are (pre)determined. This is generally described as a situation where all events are caused, completely and entirely, by preceeding events. Thus all events form a giant chain, where A causes B causes C, and so on, from the very first event through to the very last. Such an arrangement leaves no room for the idea that we can events, since everything is fixed. Thus there is no room for (incompatibalist) free will. One problem with this view of the universe is that science has generally suggested it to be nonsense. Modern physics is full of random events, that is events that can not be predicted, even in theory. Godel did some very good work in proving this mathematically. From here there are two places to go. You can either go with Hard Determinism, the idea that universe really is determined, it’s just determined by a means we don’t know about yet. So it’s theoretically possible that we will in the future come across a determinist theory for everything that does away with random events. However, it’s not a popular theory at the moment, and there’s no particular reason to believe this will happen. The alternative approach is Soft Determinism, which is basically Determinism with random events. All events are deemed to be either (pre)determined, or entirely random, with no other type of event allowed. This saves its adherants from contradicting current science, while still denying free will. Again, though, there is no particular reason to believe this to be the case, and it relies on an essentially arbitrary division of the universe into two types of events. Free will ends up being denied just because it doesn’t fit into this arbitrary framework. Futhermore, I’d suggest that determinism itself is flawed. Our understanding of events relies on local causation, that is, that events that happen are the product of what we see around us. If you cross the road, and get hit by a car, you’d explain the accident in terms of the care with which you crossed the road, the attention of the driver, the speed of the vehicle, the traction of the road surface, and so on. You wouldn’t cite the composition of the universe immediately after the Big Bang. Yet under determinism, the Big Bang is the best explanation for you being hit. All other possible factors are just local approximations, inaccurate proxies for what really determined the accident, which was the composition of the universe at the start of time. Determinism ends up being deeply hostile to cause and effect as we generally understand it. As such, I’d suggest that free will, no matter how you define it, is almost certainly true. There’s nothing in science or logic to discount it. The only reason to dismiss it is if you believe, a priori, that the structure of the universe is such that all events must be pre-determined (or random). While this belief is well-established amongst several major US educational establishments, there doesn’t appear to be any obvious reason to regard it as true. It’s not necessary for science, and it’s deeply hostile to our ideas around cause and effect.

Yes, free will exists. It exists because if I am presented with a choice between A or B I can freely choose between A or B, and no one nor any one thing can force me to choose one way or another. Even if someone threatens me if I choose A, I can still be stubborn and choose A, whatever the consequences. Some people might say free will doesn't exist because there are only 2 types of events: events that are caused by something else and events that are not, and that the universe is either deterministic (no free will), or random (no free will).I think there is a flaw in the reasoning there, and it lies in the perspective they choose in order to answer the question. Say I am presented with a choice between a tuna and a cheese sandwich, and before choosing anything I ask two different people who believe the universe is deterministic to explain to me why I have chosen what I chose. Person 1 I will lie to and say I chose tuna, and person 2 I will lie to and say I chose cheese. Now they both will come with a similar explanation and both will conclude that I have chosen either tuna or cheese because of what they just said. But I have not chosen at all. So since there is no conceivable way to prove them wrong at all by making a choice, any choice, and they cannot both be right as they contradict each other in the final part of the choice, there is a problem with their theory. The perspective of looking backwards in time and finding a set of possible causal events chaining into the choice and explaining it does not have a lot of merit for this question. They can find causes leading to tuna and causes leading to cheese, but I haven't even chosen yet. The reason for this is that the brain and all its processes involved cannot be tracked and cannot be completely followed. They are a black box, and assuming that a black box contains only deterministic paths is an assumption, just like assuming that free will happens inside that black box, with your conscious choice affecting the outcome as an extra ingredient on top of the input. As long as the black box is not completely transparent (and I am not sure it's even theoretically possible for it to be) there cannot be any definitive answer that includes the black box. Then what remains is that from the perspective of me myself looking forward (since looking backwards doesn't have merit, and looking at it from an external point doesn't either because of the black box) I see I can choose either tuna or cheese, so yes, there is free will. It's the only valid reference point from where to answer the question. One last addition to the statement that there is either a determined universe or a random universe: I think it's possible that the universe is determined by our choice. Looking forward from myself as reference point again: It's not random whether I will choose cheese or tuna, as I can choose. It's not determined what I will choose, since I can still choose. If I choose tuna I will live in a universe where I have chosen tuna, and if I choose cheese I will live in a universe where I have chosen cheese.Of course from any given point I can trace a direct line back to my first choice, and even understand my choices, but that doesn't mean the universe is determined... Well, it has been determined NOW, but looking to the future, that future still needs to be determined by our choices.So the PAST is determined, the future is not.Of course things happen that can be described as random, but that to me doesn't mean we live in a random universe either. It's a mix of the two, and most randomness could probably have theoretically been predicted. The past is determined, the future is still undetermined, and our choice turns one into the other. (Scientific calculations and precognition can predict the future, and the less dependent on choice the calculation or precognition is the more reliable the result). But I am just a guy not really knowing a lot about this all, so I could be making some mistakes in my reasoning. If so, please point them out, always good to learn :)

TL;DR Total free will does not exist, but with the use of technology you can strive to get closer to it. As long as we are constrained by needs that we cannot control it is very difficult to talk about free will. Some of these constraints are your basic physical needs like eating or having a warm shelter going to more subtle ones such as social interaction, finding love or self actualization. A few hundred years ago, covering your basic needs took up most of your time. Most of the people were working in agriculture and having a shelter or avoiding diseases took a big effort. There was very little time left to do whatever you wished. Nowadays thanks to the industrial revolution and the good side of globalization you can cover your basic needs quite cheaply. You still have to take time for things like eating, grocery shopping or paying your bills but the chunk of time that you can use to do whatever you want can be greatly increased. It all comes down to proper time management and focus. Now that you have a good part of the day to exercise free will you hit another problem. Your freedom (and therefore free will) is constrained by other people around you. You cannot have total freedom without affecting other people's free will. If you would land alone on a deserted island, you would be free. If a second person would land there, your complete freedom ends at that moment. So you can achieve a certain amount of free will in some aspects of life, but total free will is just an illusion.

Yes and no. It depends on one’s frame of reference. Universal Frame of Reference: Free will requires causality sequencing: Choice >>> Decision >>> Action. Thus, causality demands linear time. However, linear time does not exist in the Universe, it is an artefact of the metazoan brain and an illusion of the observer’s mind. Moreover, causality breaks down even further if faster-than-light travel could ever be achieved by anything (especially information) in the Universe. Hence, in this frame of reference Free Will does not exist.  However, this is what happens when you shift to: Personal Frame of Reference: Our self does not inhabit the Universal Reality but a very limited and heavily perceptually filtered reality: we can only experience the dimensionally-reduced shadows of Reality as it casts its shadows on the walls of the cave of our limited mammalian brain. In this reality time not only exists but it is also has an irrefutable direction. Causality may be perceived in an edited delay yet it has very real consequences: you push the glass over the edge and the glass falls and breaks. And you decided to push it. Was it freely?  This is what a though looks like: the timed (simultaneous or sequential) coactivations of neurons. Our brains are part of the Universe. And yet they contain a perceived universe within. And in that universe, Free Will is as real as our past. Because the truth is, when we make a decision, that decision is made by everything we ever saw, heard, touched, read, felt, imagined or experienced. Like a steel ball dropping down a long pachinko panel, seemingly free - yet able to bounce only within the paths set down pin by pin by our past. In other words, in our Personal Frame of reference, we do have Free Will - but only as much as our subconscious mind allows us to have.

I’ve long found the question of free will to be dubious in substance. Of course we have free will. What we don’t have is pure free will. In other words, there are a variety of influences upon us — social, cultural, parental, psychological — that will affect our choices and decisions, but we also have intellect, experience, wisdom and the advice of others as additional influences. Admittedly, some people exhibit more free will than others, but it’s still there in all of us. Well-balanced individuals have the most free will because they are more centrist and sensible, and likely to be more pragmatic as well. Others simply don’t have the skills to exercise their free will wisely. When free will is associated religion, the discussion will become progressively more pointless. Mixing superstition, mysticism and dogma will turn the topic into nonsense. Free will is a human attribute that exists for the same reasons we have social skills and moral-ethical awareness. Free will is not good versus evil, a simplistic world view at best. You’ve got free will, and if you think you don’t, see a therapist. Like critical thinking, free will requires doing the work of thinking things through with an open mind and nuance. Philosophically, if you’re a rational agent, you have free will. Enjoy it. “Strong” free will, the freedom of will from all causality, is of course a load of nonsense, but some “weak” free will definitions, such as “the ability to consciously decide what to do”, are still perfectly valid concepts. I don’t usually agree with anything Nietzsche says, but on this issue he was absolutely correct when he wrote, “The longing for “freedom of the will” in the superlative metaphysical sense (which, unfortunately, still rules in the heads of the halfeducated), the longing to bear the entire and ultimate responsibility for your actions yourself and to relieve God, world, ancestors, chance, and society of the burden – all this means nothing less than being that very causa sui and, with a courage greater than Munchhausen’s, pulling yourself by the hair from the swamp of nothingness up into existence. Suppose someone sees through the boorish naivete of this famous concept of “free will” and manages to get it out of his mind; I would then ask him to carry his “enlightenment” a step further and to rid his mind of the reversal of this misconceived concept of “free will”: I mean the “un-free will,” which is basically an abuse of cause and effect. We should not erroneously objectify “cause” and “effect” like the natural scientists do (and whoever else thinks naturalistically these days –) in accordance with the dominant mechanistic stupidity which would have the cause push and shove until it “effects” something; we should use “cause” and “effect” only as pure concepts, which is to say as conventional fictions for the purpose of description and communication, not explanation.” Now, some people will tell you that we can’t actually consciously decide on what to do because all our choices are made by our brains, but this is only true if you subscribe to material reductionism. These very same people will also tell you that we are nothing more than our brains, but what they ignore is that if we really are our brains then it logically follows that our brains are also us. I think science is somewhat divided on this one - and it’s not even clear what “free will” actually means. From all we can tell from what we’ve found out about brains - they are basically a lot like computers. Very, very complicated computers - and computers that aren’t very accurate or perfect in their operations - but basically computers. There isn’t much scientific debate about THAT. So this leads to a few questions: Can a computer be programmed to have free will? — Most people would say “No.”Can a computer be programmed to think that it has free will? — Most people would say “Yes.” Line 423: “if ( askedAboutFreeWill ) print “Yes, I have free will!”;So that means that the impressions we have of free will could be entirely false. There have been studies done in MRI machines that suggest that it could be a false impression. I forget the exact details - but it was something like: They put people into a brain scanner with two buttons they could press - and when a light came on, asked them to pick which button they wanted to press at random - then to press it - and to do this as fast as they possibly could after the light came on. They also asked people to repeat the experiment - but this time, after deciding which button to push - to NOT press either button - so make the decision, but take no action. In the second run of the experiment they could see which parts of the brain were responsible for the decision-making and in the first experiment they could see both the part that made the decision and the part that commanded the finger to move and press the button. What they found (surprisingly) was that most of the time, people pressed the button and THEN the decision making part of the brain became active. We decide which button to press about a half second after we’ve already pressed it! This suggests that the “free will”decision making was merely the conscious part of the brain doing an after-the-fact rationalization for why the lower brain functions picked a button at random. That makes it seem like the conscious mind is simply choosing to apply labels to things that already happened - and the memory that is stored is that the conscious mind issued a command and the subconscious did what it was told…when in fact the reverse was the case. That said, other scientists say that in a sufficiently complex system - and especially one with imperfect logic - that self-awareness might just be an emergent property of complexity. So right now - the jury is out. We don’t know either way for sure. I’d bet good money we’ll figure it out within the next 10 years.

If anyone ever tries to give you an answer other than “No one knows,” then ignore them. This question is as old as humanity and probably can never truly be answered at all. The answer for you is what you choose to believe, or believe you were fated to believe respectively. However, physics does provide something interesting and relevant to this discussion. Quantum mechanics is, according to the most current understanding the best and brightest minds studying it can produce, probabilistic. That means that the tiniest pieces of our universe do not follow set paths determined by neat equations, but rather “roll the dice” and then decide based on that idea of random chance. Bell's Theorem was experimentally verified and peer-reviewed, and it proved that basically nothing that travels at or below the speed of light in a vacuum could possibly explain quanum randomness as the results of as-yet undetected particles or phenomena. So, essentially, either something that travels faster than light is telling quantum particles what to do before they do it (doubtful, becuase nothing made of matter can travel faster than light and scientists have never observed anything traveling faster than light period), or quantum truly is probabilistic. That leaves determinism in an uncomfortable position as it was based on the idea of an orderly, predictable universe. Accoridng to the physicist who devised Bell's Theorem in the first place, he sees only one way to salvage determinism: super-determinism. This view holds that every single quantum fluctuation that ever has and will ever occur was decided the moment the Big Bang happened. However, many people including myself believe this makes existence itself vacuous. For instance, not only would I have been fated to type this the instant the universe was born, it wouls be impossible for me to NOT type this. Under this perspective, consciousness and individuality do not exist. Humans are functionally no differrnt from a rock or leaf. We are like the white froth at the peak of a breaking wave: fascinating and complex, but ultimately just another meshing together of physical particles. You lose the ability to make decisions because decisions do not exist, consciousness does not exist, and therefore you and I and every other “living” thing does not truly exist any more than a whirlpool in water is any different from the water that surrounds it. You might see the problems this view raises. But, according to physicist's best understanding of quantum mechanics and the extrapolated philosophy that comes with it, you have only two choices: free will or super-determinism.

Yes, within the quantum behavior of our neural synapses. *** Those who disagree are working from a 19th century cosmological model called "the clockwork universe." This model says every action arises directly from preceding actions in a linear way - as if every prior cause, working in confluence with all other prior causes, can produce only one particular result. Anyone familiar with photon behavior knows this isn't true. Just as a photon may be seen as a particle or as a wave - depending upon how it is observed - so effects may arises from probable, rather than definitive, causes. *** The world is probabilistic, not deterministic. This means a myriad of causes conjoin to produce an effect which is probable, not certain.  This machine, called a Galton Board, shows how probability works. Hundreds of balls of the same size and weight are dropped from a single hole at the top-center of the machine. For our purposes, think of each ball as a prior cause. After the drop the same mountain peak always appears. Most balls fall into the center slots and fewer fall into the outer slots. The pattern remains the same...but where any individual ball will fall is a matter of random chance. In quantum indeterminacy, all prior causes form such a pattern prior to any given outcome. Even if we could trace all prior causes in our behavior we still cannot know which cause will "decide" what we do next, because the distribution of prior causes is random. A strong cause may, by happenstance, appear at the outer edges of the decision-making field; a weak cause may wind up on top. The image above - an array of prior causes extant before an event (a human decision) - exists in a state of quantum superposition. This means prior causes come together in all possible states simultaneously...so long as we don't observe the field. Once we "look to check" our own superposition of causes, then an effect (a choice) can be made. We are always checking our own mentality to see what we might do next. How we view our past determines what we do...not the past itself.

Free will is loosely defined abstract based on other loosely defined abstracts. It means you are able to make choices - but what exactly makes "you", "being able to" and "choices"? You can bend those definitions to your need, whether you want to believe in free will or not.  For example if you assume there has to be a core of personality independent of every external factor (like genetics and upbringing) to make choices - free will is only possible with assumption of existence of some kind of a soul or spirit that can operate on it's own. "Bob chose to go to church" in that case means that either Bob's soul's true nature made him go to church and the whole world could only affect his decision to some degree, or - souls don't exists, Bob was programmed by his parents to go to church and the sentence is a lie. However, if you can consider a person as whole, including all effects of external events, a grand sum of genetics, upbringing, environment, recent actions, metabolism and so on - so defined actor can make choices and it's compatible with determinism.  "Bob decided to go to church" in this case are just another words to say "Bob went to church because he was raised in religious family" because it just means "Out of a complex being we call Bob, the part that was determined by religious upbringing played major role in making decision to go to church. But that is still a part of Bob's nature so it's still his choice".   So, words are kind of elastic and with little effort you can bend them to have fit any approach. The question is - which approach is better. In my opinion, philosophy should eventually answer "so what should I do with that?" rather than "how do we name stuff?" question.In this case, it means "How should I treat people if they have free will? Heuristics and cognitive biases can be changed, and logical fallacies corrected, intentionally. Although changing them is difficult and requires great effort. Whereas confidence and mindfulness (presence of mind) can lead to free will, for all intents and purposes. My take on Free Will (FW) is that really it's a verb, a behaviour that occurs. You can't put "a" Free Will into a box. FW isn't a 'thing' you can find somewhere if you cut open a brain or looked under a microscope. FW only applies, by definition, to certain objects: specifically living objects. FW is a concept. It is a concept (verb, behaviour) performed by specific objects.  The question is WHY? Why do we apply this term to human beings, or perhaps insects or trees, but not rocks? This is what I think: as an object in and of itself (i.e. not dissecting us into smaller parts), a human shows a type of motion that's of a higher order of unpredictability than inanimate objects like rocks, shoes, atoms. And more complex even than living things like trees or bacteria. But I think 'life' is really the beginning of Free Will because the motion displayed by living objects is unpredictable, and there's a scale of complexity here that goes from purely gravitational, through atomic, through molecular (i.e. chemical) right up to "life".  Here's my stab at it:  – L1 motion : Gravitational : Inanimate. Rocks, shoes, planets. Hyper predictability. Completely slave to gravitational forces. I drop a ball, it falls as expected. It doesn't spontaneously fly away or stop rolling or jump.   – L2 motion : Atomic : Inanimate. Hyper predictability, but not explicable ONLY by gravitational forces. E.g. bonding (covalent, ionic). Perhaps electrical, magnetic.   – L3 : (Inter)molecular : Inanimate. Still a prredictable motion. Molecular structures, inter-molecular bonding. Not entirely explicable by gravitational or atomic forces, but require studying molecular transformations.   – L4-L5 : Life and/or 'Free Will' : Animate (aka "volition"). Motion "willed by" a brain. What we internally experience as 'choice' (subjective, irrelevant). We 'choose to' stand or jump against gravity, i.e. we objectively can act against (unpredictably) the external G, A, M forces, while a corpse (predictably) cannot. Highest level of unpredictability.  Note that we must NOT do mereology in order to understand this. It is easy to argue that we never "really" escape Gr, At or Chem forces because we are also made of the same atoms, molecules etc – and thus there is some internal chain of events that must be an explanation for the "seeming" magical act of "defying" gravity e.g. when we stand or jump. However, this goes into nonsensical and circular Free Will vs Determinism arguments, which are heavily influenced by religion.  We escape this mereology and contradiction by remembering that we are talking about the object 'human being' or 'rock' in totality, not its constituent parts or internal functions. We're interested in the net result, the objective behaviour. In order to explain the behaviour of a given object, we must take that object as its whole, else we contradict ourselves and end up in murky water. Of course gravity and atomic forces act on us perpetually, just as chemical and electrical and magnetic ones do. But for the purpose of explaining Free Will scientifically i.e. objectively, we ignore internal processes. Because the focus of the study, of the main question, is the behaviour of the specific object in its entirety.  To conclude: Free Will is the highest level (L4) of unpredictable motion that living objects such as humans have acquired organically; behaviour which cannot ALONE be explained by purely gravitational, atomic, or chemical events. There is a unique internal physical process going on that allows the object in question to temporarily fight against EXTERNAL push-pull influences in a highly unexpected fashion.

“Of course we have free will. We have no choice” - Christopher Hitchens Leaving aside how I loved his wit, irony and charisma, it certainly feels like we do. However, a number of neurologists disagree with that. Given that I just quoted Hitchens, I can’t refrain from talking about Sam Harris[1][2], another of the four horsemen. Basically the idea is that it is possible to demonstrate experimentally how your brain does all the deciding before you’re even aware of it. The argument goes all the way back to Laplace’s Demon[3] and the notion of causal determinism. In a nutshell, the argument goes like: if there was such an entity (the demon) that knew at any given moment the position and momentum of every particle in the universe, it could theoretically predict the future as all those particles would have one, and only one way of moving forward, given their position, momentum and the laws of physics. The argument has been stretched to the brain and consciousness because they are (or arise from) a physical system that, as complex as it may be, has to follow exact laws, even if we don’t know them exactly at this time. Now, some have started introducing the concept of quantum physics to consciousness[4] as well (not like Deepak Chopra, I’m talking about serious scientists, the likes of Sir Roger Penrose[5][6] or Jim Al-Khalili[7][8][9][10]). Of course, several interpretations of quantum mechanics also leave space for hidden variables and an underlying determinism[11], like De Broglie-Bohm’s or the most mainstream Many worlds interpretation so it’s still entirely possible. To recap: feels like we do, but most of what we’ve discovered so far seems to point out that we really haven’t. In the end, it remains to be seen. Stay tuned. What does “free will” mean? Practically speaking, from a legal standpoint it means that an individual makes an individual and relatively uncoerced action, and so should be held responsible for the consequences of that action. Whether the purpose of the justice system is punative, or to isolate individuals who are likely to harm others this notion of free will would exist even in a strictly deterministic universe. (However we don’t, I should mention, live in a strictly deterministic universe) Neurologically, many of our decisions are made first, and then justified later by our neocortex. This argument regarding free will assumes that ‘free will’ is identical to neocortical processing and the conscious mind, which one might disagree with. It also disregards possible neocortical feedback after the fact. When you have to make a split second decision, you may make that decision based on instinct. But when you have time later to consider your decision, there’s the potential to alter your instincts. For those who consider ‘free will’ to be identical to neocortical processing, this allows free will to exist.

Will is a feeling of intent and determination. If you feel it, you know it exists. The problematic part is “free” which can be given different meanings. The legal meaning is that you were not subject to coercion (and there can be degrees of coercion and so degrees of “free”). The religious/libertarian idea of “free” is “capable of violating physical laws”. There’s no reason to suppose that kind of “free” exists. The compatibilist idea of “free” means “Determined by you who you are. Your values, experiences, genetics, etc.” It’s sort of the metaphysical complement of the legal definition. The operational definition of “free” is: not predictable, even by you. Think what it would take for you to NOT feel you had free will. Suppose you could examine and analyze your brain and how it got the memories and values it holds, so that you could look at it and say, “Yes, now I see that I had to do that. My action was determined by the physics and chemistry of my brain” then you might no longer feel “free”.

Viewing the individual from the outside, his behavior is determined by various factors, and is, in theory, predictable. So the determinist says, behavior is predictable, there is no free will. Viewed subjectively, from the point of view of the individual actor, he appreciates being free to make his own choices. So, if I have a glass of whiskey every evening at 6 pm, the determinist says, my behavior can be predicted based on heredity, habit, culture, family dynamics, and so on, therefore I do not have free will. I say, I am freely choosing to have my evening whiskey. My free will would be impaired if my wife poured out the whiskey before I could drink it. Theologically, the concept of free will is a response to the problem of evil. If God is all good and all powerful, why is there evil in the world? Answer: because God allows us to exercise “free will.” If I go to murder my wife, God does not paralyze me or strike the gun from my hand. So the murder is my fault. And since God purposely refrained from making us his puppets, my evil deed is not a flaw in his creation. The determinist, on the other hand, says, the murder was predictable, a product of my nature and the circumstances, so where’s my free will? I suspect he might be right. But, taken to the extreme, this could suggest that my evil deed was “written” or “fated” and I had no choice in the matter. Perhaps I should not even be punished! Yet that seems an odd conclusion. And it’s wrong. One of the many factors that goes into my behavior is the judgment of other humans. If I hurt my wife, I might go to prison. My children might never speak to me again. If I’m religious, I might fear God’s judgment as well. So if the threat of punishment or disapproval were removed, there would be more bad behavior. Human society works because we hold each other responsible for our actions, and we should continue to do so — regardless of whether philosophers tell us those actions are “free” or “determined.”

Answer: No (tl;dr at the bottom) I think an important thing to start with when discussing such a topic is to define some of your terms I shall define “free will” as the ability to make a decision such that you could have chosen otherwise. (I must thank Matt Acutt for this succinct definition) The only other term I think I will need is “self”. As I define this term it should hopefully become clear why I hold my current view point on free will. My definition of self is likely very similar as others, with one small caveat. I believe that if you are exactly the same person presented with exactly the same decision and given exactly the same information you will make exactly the same choice. Since the choice you made is based on your current beliefs and desires, that means that you ability to make a decision is directly tied to your current beliefs, and desires. And where did you get those beliefs and desires? You got them from your experiences, and the experiences of those around you. Sure it may seem like you have control of which experiences you have, but the experiences you choose are again directly influenced by your previous experiences. You can follow this all the way back to the very first thing you ever experienced, likely before you were even born. In my opinion the free will debate was never about your ability to make a decision, that is a given. The debate is about whether you were ever able to make a different decision from the one you think is best based on your current self. tl;dr Your decisions are based on your beliefs, your beliefs are based on your experiences, and the experiences you have were outside your control until long after your self was defined. Yes you chose to eat spaghetti for dinner, but you were always going to chose that based on who you were in the moment.

Chapter I Free will is a problem, which worries us all because not only it affects our morality and judgement of someone conducting amoral and even violent acts, but also free will is what makes up our personality, our feeling of self. Without it, we are merely biological robots with an illusion of being in charge of something. Simply put - Within a physical system everything is predisposed, in other words, all events possess causal events that precede them in time. Some say it can be true for the classical Newtonian system and Quantum Mechanics proves the existence of free will, but this is plain wrong. First of all, we aren’t sure of the nature of QM, there are different interpretations. For instance, Bohmian interpretation is deterministic and completely neglects the probabilistic nature of the Copenhagen interpretation. If the latter is true, you still don’t get free will by any means. In this case, so-called free will becomes a result of probabilistic events and you aren’t in charge of them. It has been around for ages. The key point is that if you know all the properties of the current state, you can calculate precisely what is going to happen in the future. Thinkers back in the days used a demon or some super-intelligent theoretical creature, which could do the task. Now we can call it a super-computer, nothing’s changed since then really. Many people do not realize this problem is bound to consciousness and interactional epiphenomenalism. I.E The brain affects conscious states and vice versa, consciousness also affects the brain. While this stance really begs a good clarification and studies, we already know certain conscious states have their respective neural correlates (just for the sake of simplicity let’s avoid details here). Thus, doing different mental tasks result in activating different brain areas. Whether it’s a good argument for the interactional nature of consciousness or not, we need to determine what sparkles an intentional action. There are three possibilities. You believe you have free will and also a capacity to execute it.You believe things, including your brain and voluntary actions, are inevitable and already determined years ago.You are compatibilist, admitting the existence of both free will and inevitability.The first variant is dubious and arbitrary, why? Because it involves a kind of “magical force” - a conscious decision, which affects matter and is capable of altering neural activity. This raises a couple of problems. A) A conscious decision can’t fit within the materialistic framework because it’s undefinable, irreducible and a non-physical state. To affect matter you need to have matter itself. B) We don’t have an established scientific model of how consciousness changes matter, though some clear indications exist many thinkers are unaware of, or they simply dismiss them.  Chapter II In the 80s, Benjamin Libet conducted experiments which are still debatable years later. He was a pioneer to scientifically determine if a voluntary decision was conscious, or unconscious and then translated as conscious without being aware of it. Libet asked subjects to flex their wrist a number of times whenever they wished and measured the time at which the action was executed, the brain activity in motor cortex and the time at which the subjects decided to act consciously. The settings of the experiments were easy, he put electrodes on the wrist to detect the action through electromyography (EMG) and put another set of electrodes on the scalp to record the activity using electroencephalography (EEG). EEG records a signal also called readiness potential (RP), which is gradually increasing. To measure a conscious decision, he placed a clock in front of the subjects and they had to follow the hand of the clock and remember where the spot was when they made a decision. Therefore, after the experiment, they could report the place of the hand and determine the time of the decision. Libet asked what happened first in time, the readiness potential (brain activity) or a conscious decision? A decision happened 200 milliseconds before the action, but the readiness potential started 350 milliseconds before that (i.e in total, 550 milliseconds before the action - wrist flexion). Simply put, the brain activity preceded the conscious decision to move. 550 milliseconds is nothing from our scale but for the brain, it’s a very, very long time to conduct certain events at the molecular level. Again, we have some issues. This experiment was perceived as wrong and ridiculed by many. Dan Dennett argued that the validity of the timing of conscious desire to move should be doubted because Libet wasn’t fully depended on objective measures and partly relied on subjective reports from the subjects. Dennett notes that the report is where it seems to the subject to have taken a decision, not the actual time, which has to be measured objectively. After all, visual inputs have to be processed first and there is no other way around besides the clock-dot method to measure the subjective decision. Well, there might be more sophisticated methods but they still have to rely on subjective reports and the input still goes through the same brain structures. So the gap between the decision and the readiness potential can probably be filled by this argument. Flexing wrists can’t be compared to making complex decisions that involve personhood, the past, moral and other factors such as marriage or adopting pets. It would be a very trivial generalization to take for granted but the result is there nonetheless. Libet himself didn’t claim anything over the topic, he never stated free will as an illusory misperception. I think, at heart, he knew something could be wrong with these experiments. He developed a new experiment in which subjects had to abort their movement. In other words, they terminated the conscious decision, this resulted in the following - The readiness potential began as normal, but gradually disappeared 200 milliseconds before the planned action. Libet called this phenomenon ‘free won’t’. Chapter III To summarize those two experiments above, consciousness can’t initiate a conscious decision to move, but it can prevent it. Thus, we still have the freedom to choose. Does it mean consciousness affect the brain, the matter? Yes.Does it fit within a deterministic physical system from orthodox physicists’ standpoint? Apparently not. We may think this saves free will within the determined machine but free won’t is still odd, because it involves consciousness, a non-physical ‘force’. (Don’t get confused with pranic energy or similar mystical concepts, I just use those words to put it belletristically.)If there is a space for ‘free won’t’ does it mean the first experiment could’ve been wrong and we also have free will? Yes, absolutely.If we have free will/free won’t, are we capable of executing the full potential of them in daily lives? I don’t think so, we are so bounded by the events outside, free will is probably a prisoner. Of course, you can choose a colour of your shirt and that kind of stuff but from my point of view, that’s not much. I hate labels as they are arbitrary and do not express my views completely but you could say, I am kind of compatibilist.

We are the victims of our own existence. Some may reject this statement for moral or self-deluded reasons. The truth is we can’t overlook the fundamental fact, the fact that there is no such thing as free will (I am discussing here from the ultimate perspective, not the proximal perspective). We exist in an existential box. Of course, the universe is very likely to exist as infinite and incomprehensible forms of reality (we can never know). We all, were born and will be born in a box that is constructed of time and space. The existence of time and space only make sense, however, (but does not depend on) when a human specie who can communicate with each other through a language exists and objects have the property of dynamic transformation or change. At the surface level (and even at more deeper levels), nothing is constant. The human perceived reality is a product of individual and collective consciousness and that consciousness is a created tool for evolutionary human specie to overly simplify its existence. Our body and brain are the product of chemical reactions and combinations triggered by energy. Energy is absorbed from the surrounding environments. Our consciousness is capable of operation only and only through the combination of the right chemicals and innate traits hiding in our cells. Our desires are always and randomly determined by biological mechanisms and processes within our biological brain or body. The truth is that every crimes people have committed or every donations that they have made were determined by their designated brain, the brain that has been developed for millions of years by evolution and several years by social and cultural experiences. Because of all these interactions between our evolutionary past and our current state of existence in ecological, social and political contexts, our free wills are ultimately shaped. Often, we confuse these determined freedoms with local (proximal) free wills, the free wills that are taken out of the context of other interrelated factors. Some argued, “I can eat a pizza anytime I want or I can decide to never eat it until I die. This is my freedom to make a decision or fulfil my desire. Therefore, a free will exists within me.” The funny thing is that they forget to consider what makes them want or need to eat that pizza or other foods in the first place. And also, we tend to ignore another parts that are affected while we try to pursue a supposed free will. Every action that is designed to make the human world a little better, that action is also equally and unintentionally designed to destroy another worlds that are socially, psychologically and physically distance from the human specie, directly or indirectly. It might be tempting to believe that we have the power to manipulate a goal and create a destiny. But if we dare enough to look past our personal ignorances or heuristic perceptions of the world, there are dead ends in all directions. We are born, matured and decayed in an existential box with no real way out. That’s the main reason why people created or create religions, the symbolic realities that allow them to escape the box through their imaginations and rituals. If they keep believing in what they have created by engaging some kind of rituals or thoughts, one day it will make it hard for them to separate the symbolic reality from the physical reality. This might be a sign of mental illness if it is created by a person with the history of schizophrenia. But if several people join this kind of an imagined reality, then that reality is termed ‘the higher truth of existence’ of a religion. This is the first path, the path that denies reality or existential threats such as death by creating a symbolic/inter-subjective reality. The second path is to accept that we exist in a box with no way out and pay heavy prices through psychological torments. Every truth that we, as collective human civilisations, have ever dug up, one way or another, one time or another, end up as a simple or sophisticated illusion disguised as an absolute truth. Every accepted truth that any great scientist or philosopher has ever revealed is simply just another relative truth in a deeper dimension of reality. These people, in the end, not so different from those who choose to create or be part of a shared delusion. Just because we have the ability to measure, record, categorise and verbalise abstract ideas and concrete objects, does it mean that what our findings about the universe and the supposed reality are real or the absolute truth exists? The question is, do we even have the real ability to categorise? Or is it simply that we linguistically think and socially agree that we have? When we have been bathed in a bath of illusory truths for too long, we can see no further bigger pictures of our own reality and reality of the world we are a part of. We can’t see beyond of what we can perceive and sense or beyond of what we as a collective group have created throughout history. More than sometimes, we confuse the ultimate difference between human created or percieved truths and the truth that is truely and absolutely universal that is extending beyond a collective, comprehensible mind of any species on earth. It is very painful once we have intellectually deported ourself out of the box, consciously and intentionally. There is no way back to blindness. At the first phase of realisation, past and future run over us while we are forced to carve millions and millions of coffin for our present moments. Our sense of present might inititally give way to uncontrollable thoughts that lead to decayed perception of the universe with dried tears or laughters. We have realised too much that we might become paralysed or overwhelmed for many days and nights. We might wish we can turn back the time when we can still exist within that box as an ignorant being with egoistic viewpoints toward outside world and our inner reality, so that we can freely allow our blood running through our veins whenever we are angry. But this is just a short-term wish. No one truely wants to be a blind bat forever. Knowing that truth reduces our ability to pause, and kiss. We have lost our attentional ability that is designed to focus in the present. Everything we perceive become equally significance or insignificance at the same time. Our mind is invaded. Money and a raindrop has become equally meaningful or meaningless. A white rhino, the last of its kind, in the West Africa and a 1000 years old tree in the Amazon are equally important or unimportant. A red rose that we hold one morning and a beautiful lady we speak to one evening are equally attractive to our heart or insignificant to our soul. This is because that realisation has removed our ego and we become part of the universe. Every objects and subjects become equal without a little bit of discrimination. You can find us as a green grass under a soldier’s boot or as a crown on a queen’s head. Nothing is specific and nothing is concrete. There is no black or white. Everything converge into the same entity and that entity has no fixed names or fixed values. Life and death becomes the same source of pain at that point. The truth is that entity itself is not even an entity in our mind. Realising that we can’t live beyond the limited dimensional box is devastating yet it is necessary to for our authetic growth at the human level. Our highest self, a pure state of enlightenment, depends on that transition. Yet, enlightenment does not come easy. We have to pay the price with depression and helplessness to some stages. It always begins with a nihilistic phase of transition. It is not an easy fight. Once we let in the painful truth and once it spreads all over every part of our naive brain, we can’t feel no more for some times. We have no feeling for our own existence. This is how it leads some men to behave in a risky way, to engage in a risky behaviour, just so that they can get in touch with their present again whether that behaviour leads to sadnesses or death. A high degree of excitement or where the line between life and death become very blurred, become the only source to awakening from a life of existential crisis. And some men, unless they meditate on inner peace or outer beauties and courageously accepting that existential truth, will gradually or suddenly lose control of their life. Once they lose their sense of belonging for too long, they want to disappear. Road to facing the brutal fact concerning our own existence does not only deprive us of our own present moments, that realisation also murders all our meaningful actions and beliefs. It is a dangerous path to walk alone. It requires us to meditate and practice self-control. We have to love more. Sacrifice more. Only that we can live a meaningless life filled with beauties. What is more scarier than being physically and mentally attacked by existential threats, on a daily basis? And what is more to lose or gain when there is nothing to lose or gain from the first day we are given a life? Mediating on truths and engaging in compassion and self-control may also be just another delusional acts at the deepest layers of higher and inconceivable truths yet they are all we have got. Or we can choose to become a monster in this dreamy reality.

Free will of human beings and foreknowledge of God Do we have free will? If human beings have free will, then it means that they can choose between various alternatives. And as long as the choice is thus open, it is undecided and unsettled, it is uncreated. It may fall on any one of the several alternatives; which that alternative would be is not known yet. It is known to none, not even to God; for if God knows it, it means that it is already fixed and the person has no choice. Thus if human beings have free will, none can have foreknowledge. These two things, God's foreknowledge, and human free will seem to be incompatible. Again this, one may argue that God knows all things of the past, present, and the future, but that he does not interfere in people's doing. Just as someone can make a guess about future happenings and the guess may turn out to be true, similarly, God can know of future events. But as He is the most perfect being, his guesses will invariably be correct. In this manner, God may know of the future without influencing human will. Now, if we examine this kind of reasoning carefully, we find that it is fallacious and does not really prove the thing that it apparently seems to do. The first point to be noticed here is that if guesswork must invariably be true, as we believe it to be in case of God, then it ceases to be guesswork. A guess implies some degree of doubt, and as God is supposed to have no doubts, in His case it is knowledge and not guesswork. Now for the sake of argument, let us say that God only knows the future action of human beings, but does not determine them. This, however, does not help us at all in settling the question of human free will, because even if God does not determine our future actions, but only knows them, the fact that they are determined remains. Knowledge of a thing presupposes its existence. Who determines them, whether our own nature through a long chain of cause and effect or an external agency, is immaterial; for inasmuch as they are already known, and thus fixed and not left to our free choice to be made at the moment of action, they are determined or predestined for us. If a thing must happen in a certain way, although that way is to be arrived at through a long and complicated process of various cause and effect operating at different times and in different places, if the things cannot happen otherwise, then certainly it is predetermined and fixed. Foreknowledge invariably and essentially implies predestination - the questions Whose foreknowledge? and Who predetermines? do not arise. The point seems to be quite clear; for obviously until the person who has to decide between two and different alternatives is born, the decision is not made, and any one of the various alternatives is possible; thus if the thing is undecided, that is, the decision is non-existent, how can it exist or be present in the mind of God or anyone else? The decision has yet to be made by the free will of the person who is yet to be born. So long as the person is unborn, his free will is also unborn, and consequently, his decision is also unborn; it is an uncreated state; it does not exist; it does not exist even in mind of God; that is, even God does not know of it, He has no foreknowledge. Thus to all appearances, it seems that either God has foreknowledge or human beings have free will. Both things cannot be so at the same time. If they are, then it is a great and important problem for us to know how much obvious contradictions can be reconciled. What sort of God do we have who knows what we are doing and what we shall do, and still leaves it to our free choice to do whatever we like? And what sort of creatures must we be? Free Will and determinism But if a human being has no free will, then everything is fixed for him. He has no choice, and therefore the question of right and wrong does not arise; as Immanuel Kant says: "You must only if you can". Consequently, there can be no reward and punishment, no morality, no striving or struggling, and no true action. We shall, in that case, be like machines, what the French philosopher Rene Descartes call automatons, which work automatically and mechanically. However, we do have some free will called as - conditioned free will. We are like in the middle of a chess game where our free moves are conditioned by previous moves (our destiny).
