THE INNATE ORIGIN OF HUMAN FREE WILL 1. OUR TEACHER * All effects that have occurred or will ever occur must result from the original potential for them. That potential existed since the beginning. Much important potential remains with us today. We contain much more potential for learning. Who will teach us new knowledge? Do we teach one another? We feel that we teach. We talk and write and, because others appear to learn from us, we think that we are teaching them. It is believed that learning comes from the outside world. However, what we receive from others are only signs. The teacher and student are only exchanging photons. Photons are the particle nature of electromagnetism. The ongoing bombardment of a storm of photons does not deliver knowledge. That rush of wildly mixed innumerable bits of data doesn’t teach us. Who then is our teacher? We are our teacher. We learn from innate knowledge. 2. THE EXISTENCE OF INNATE KNOWLEDGE The photons come like a turbulent wind. They are signs of events occurring in the outside world for which we must recognize meanings. The photons are not the events. They are tiny bits of data about changes of velocities of particles of matter that have participated in the events. Individual photons signify tiny pieces of a complex whole. It is their arrangements that signify events in the outside world. Those unique fleeting arrangements are what we have for guidance. We, subconsciously, try to fit meanings to them. We subconsciously choose from our innate knowledge the meanings that seem to best fit the photonic evidence for events of the outside world. It can often be easy to make correct associations. When our eyes are ‘observing’ events, our subconscious mind is working wonderfully well at telling our conscious mind what we are probably seeing. An incredible amount of data is being analyzed faster than we can see. This ability could not have been acquired by repetition. There has never been repetition. The photonic arrangements are never repeated. The signs are always new. We can pick out patterns in those arrangements only if we already know those patterns. We absorb the photons. We pick out the likely patterns. We do this instinctively. Instinctive behavior is evidence for the existence of innate knowledge. Instinct means that we have the knowledge necessary to carry out an act without having previously been made aware of it. It originates from inside us. Instinctual knowledge is innate. That innate knowledge is genetically delivered to us. We do not learn meanings from signs. Words, spoken or written or, what both are physically received as, patterns of photonic bits of data, are only signs. We provide the meanings. Knowledge of meanings must already be available to us before signs can point us toward them. Since we successfully interpret the photon storm, we can know that knowledge of meanings is innate. 3. COMMUNICATING WITH EMOTIONS When our subconscious mind accepts a conclusion, the conclusion becomes a conscious thought. An emotion is communicated along with the thought. Some conclusions are accompanied by a feeling of confusion. Others by a good feeling indicating they make sense. If it weren’t for this feeling we wouldn't know the difference between a confident conclusion and a questionable one. This emotional stimulation is an important part of the means of communication between our subconscious and conscious mind. An example of emotion is the feeling of desire. We may desire a material object and upon gaining possession of it feel happy. We might smile or laugh, speak with excitement or shout triumphantly. We may gesture enthusiastically or perhaps even jump with delight. This kind of emotional feeling is tenuous. It is not the special emotion that I want to address. The special emotion identifies real happiness. It is an emotion that can point us to a universal truth. I will refer to it as joy. Joy is the feeling you experience while witnessing the birth of a loved baby. There are many examples that could be given; however, it is the uniqueness of the emotion that I wish to identify. The emotion is unique because of the responses it elicits from us. Its responses are opposite to those of the pleasure of gaining material possessions. These unexpected emotional responses are the means by which our subconscious mind differentiates between love’s happiness and possession’s happiness. Joy does not cause us to laugh. We instead tear up or cry. Joy does not cause us to squeal with delight. It cause us to become quiet. If we try to speak, we may find we have lost that ability. It does not cause us to leap into the air. It causes us to feel weak in the knees. It does not cause us to act proud and haughty. It reduces us to a posture of humility and humbleness. Joy is a wondrous example of our being directed toward a fundamental truth. It is an emotional response that lets us know that this is the real happiness we are destined to know. It is an example of our being internally directed to recognize universally set core values. It is not taught to us by other individuals. It came with us when we arrived. It is instinctual. Our emotion of joy teaches us our humanity. 4. INNATE KNOWLEDGE OF MEANINGS The concept of innate knowledge may seem uncomfortable for one trained to believe in a mechanical interpretation of the universe. However, which is more comfortable to say about our response to observing the universe? First, the universe exerted forces on us and parts of us changed their velocities. Or second, the universe communicated with us and we understood its meaning. The second description reflects our reality. The universe communicates with us and we communicate with it. The outside world is busy, and, our subconscious mind does not know what events are occurring. What it knows is that it receives data, and, it finds meanings for it. The data never stops coming. It is received and is compared to patterns and shapes stored in our subconscious mind. The subconscious mind searches for shapes that appear to be predominant. It attempts to find the most probable matches. There is incompleteness and discontinuity in photon data. That makes matching it against innate knowledge a trial and error prone process. The process is sometimes one of making a best guess. This is why optical illusions work. Even when we know the conclusion is wrong, our subconscious mind sometimes insists on its correctness. The result is that we continue to see the illusion instead of reality. Usually we perform better than that. Usually our subconscious mind delivers a vision that quite accurately portrays the outside world. Even then, it must overcome obstructions. Sometimes conscious thoughts are not accepted at face value. We can cause ourselves to think things through more thoroughly. The subconscious mind will then search longer for ideas that can improve the current level of thought. The search for best meanings can be left to stew subconsciously. A better conclusion might later burst forth as a conscious thought. Days may have passed without related thoughts, then suddenly our subconscious forces its new conclusion forward as a conscious thought. We are abruptly made aware of a better conclusion. Our mind may fill in, from its store of knowledge, what it deems to be missing meanings. For example, the mind anticipates change. That is the only kind of data it ever receives. This is why still pictures can be used to create the illusion of motion. Motion pictures do not include motion. The motion is formed in the mind. Our conclusion is wrong but our subconscious approved it. So we imagine the illusion and it becomes what we ‘see’. Our subconscious mind might fail to find meaning for the data. If our innate knowledge does not contain the necessary interpretation then, we cannot interpret that part of reality. All the senses can be working; however, the mind will not understand the data pertaining to that part of reality. The information is there. The senses are not the cause of failure. It is the missing innate knowledge that has failed us. If we do not innately know it, then we cannot consciously know it. Even when our minds contain the knowledge necessary to achieve understanding, we can fail to correctly interpret the information. The problem is that the data may be unclear. It is always imprecise. We do not experience exactness. The mind is the source of the concept of exactness because the data has never been communicated to us with exactness. Exactness is an innate idea. Continuity is also an innate idea. No living creature has ever seen a continuous line. The concepts of a line or of continuity in general are ideas that come from innate knowledge. Another example is changelessness. We have never received data about the existence of ‘no change’. The outside world data is always and only about change. The idea of changelessness is innate. We decipher the photon storm with all decisions being under our control. The conclusions reached are what we decide they will be. We control our thoughts. We are capable of breaking free from past modes of thought. We can endeavor to ‘remember’ undiscovered knowledge without the need for external signage. This self-stimulated process of discovery yields intuition. It yields foresight. People who discover these thoughts are sometimes described as having moments of brilliance. The benefit of self-stimulated access to innate knowledge is its potential for discovering advanced ideas. These ideas are the thoughts that free us from bondage to knowledge of the past and propel our thinking into the future. We can seek out these stored future thoughts if we will recognize that they are innately available waiting to be discovered. The universal cause of life gave us our innate store of subconscious knowledge and the emotions needed to confirm its presence. When our thoughts are guided along the emotion lined path of innate knowledge, we can learn to understand everything we are capable of knowing. Our innate knowledge is waiting to be ‘remembered’. 5. THE INNATE ORIGIN OF HUMAN FREE WILL We should start our search at the level where intelligence is most complete. Our inquiry should focus on human free will. Human free will is the greatest effect of the cause of life. We can trace it backwards toward its roots. The process will require more complex analysis than has been the case for the mechanical interpretation. Free will exists. We know this because we can choose to not be chained to knowledge of the past. We regularly advance into new levels of understanding that break with the past. Our subconscious allows for incomplete, even ambiguous data to be made useful. Not all pieces need to be in place, and yet we can suddenly become aware of new solutions and ideas. We subconsciously become aware of missing pieces or possible additions that were not discernable from the data. We subconsciously decide that the initial conclusion needs improved. The process is similar to that of jogging our memory. The jogging process contributes to free will. We ‘will’ more complete knowledge into conscious existence. We can trace the properties of intelligence by looking backward from its greatest result. Human free will is the ultimate result of the fundamental properties of intelligence. How does individual freedom of thought emerge from universal control? How is human free will the result? It occurs because the orderliness of the universe is not communicated to us fully intact. We are released intellectually from the control of universal determinism partly by how we view the universe and partly by how we access innate knowledge. We view the objects of the universe as being discrete. The photon data is discrete. In both cases the discreteness lacks clear direction. Continuity is needed for clear direction. Discontinuity leaves much of the interpretation process up to our innate knowledge. The uncertainty of meaning of received information is the extrinsic part of free will. It leaves it up to us to overlay our own view of continuity. We are left with the freedom to choose among meanings. Our innate knowledge is the intrinsic part of free will. None of us has the same innate knowledge or receives the same information. The meanings we choose can be different. Our individual store of knowledge is unique by virtue of what we each lack. Our unique individual abilities contribute to inexactness and incompleteness making free will uniquely individual. This flexibility of choice is the essence of free will. It is the rationing of knowledge that gives rise to free will. Change is constantly occurring everywhere in the universe. Along with that change the universe also has stability. The properties that cause change are stable. Their orderliness is what makes change purposeful. There is also an induced stability. The inducement of stability is due to commonness of culture and environment. Society introduces stability. Sharing a common environment and culture offers stability. Our culture and environment tend to establish norms for us. However, we are not fully predictable. We have different experiences. Our individual experiences activate different parts of our innate intelligence. We can escape cultural and environmental conditioning. We can compare long standing interpretations with newly ‘remembered’ innate knowledge. Behavior is repeatedly tested against internally generated choice. We can change our attitude and behavior by drawing upon our reserve of untapped knowledge. This can sometimes be a struggle that may lie dormant unless we vigorously pursue it. Any theory about the nature of reality must consider the true nature of human consciousness, and any deep analysis of consciousness will eventually lead to the problem of free will. What is free will? Does it really exist, or is it just an illusion? Psychic determinism tells us there is no free will. Everything is pre- determined. Human choices are just an illusion. In fact, we can't produce even a single random thought. To prove this to a friend of mine I once asked him to think of a number. Any number would work, but I asked him to think of a really big number. That was just a little trick to make things easier for me. He knew I had read many books of psychoanalysis and that I had a lot of practice interpreting my friends' dreams, so he knew what was coming next. I was going to interpret the "randomly" selected number he would chose with the same interpretation techniques I had used to interpret his dreams and the dreams of others. The number he chose was 65900545. Now, as I said, asking for a large number was a trick to make things easier for me, the interpreter. In fact, a large number is actually composed of multiple numbers. So I started the interpretation, asking him to make free associations. «What comes to your mind when you think about the number 65 millions?» I asked. After thinking about it for a split second, he said «Dinosaurs». I guess the reason is that dinosaurs populated the earth till 65 millions years ago, but the reason is not really important. He already knew he should not reason over the answer, but just say what first came to his mind. Now, «Dinosaurs» was an answer that told me nothing yet, so I asked for more associations. «Give me three words to describe dinasaurs,» I said. «They were huge, they lived before man was born... and they had to fight to survive.» These were his answers. Now, the first two were obvious references to his parents: they were huge [like seen from a baby's point of view], they lived before my friend [the man] was born, and so I thought the third one was probably also a reference to his mother and father. They had to fight to survive. I didn't know much about the story of his parents at the time, so I asked him for a few details, and he confirmed my thoughts. They came from the southern part of the country looking for jobs, as a young couple with a baby. They were not rich and had to work very hard to build a future and live in a beautiful hose. Now, it's much easier to interpret a dream, or, as in this case, a number, a product of someone's subconscious, if you already know the person well. I knew my friend had been recently forced, by his parents, to buy a house for himself. He was a young man with a job, but he was still living in his parents house, with little or no expenses. This is not so uncommon in Italy. He could have bought a nice car, he could have spent some of his money on nice holydays, or just having fun around, living a carefree life. But his parents had forced him to buy a house, and to rent it, to get an income that would partially cover the mortgage instalment. They had forced him to invest for his future. I had already interpreted most of the number's meaning before even getting past the number 65 million and its connection with dinosaurs. A few more questions and answers revealed that the "900" was his mortgage rounded up and the "500" was the income he was getting from the rent, rounded down. Furthermore, "45" was the age he was going to be when the mortgage was going to be fully repaid. Now, the interpretation of a dream, or, in this case, of a number, has to deal with the emotional life of the person who has the dream. There are two kinds of thoughts in our minds, at any given moment: important thoughts, which are emotionally charged, and unimportant thoughts, which are emotionally neutral. Our subconscious always concern itself with important thoughts only. When we are talking about the weather, or any other trivial topic that we don't really care about, our subconscious constantly express hidden references and symbols, depicting our current emotional state. And it does that with words and gestures, using the language of symbols. Sometimes it uses symbols that symbolyze other symbols, like the number 65 millions, which symbolize dinosaurs, which in turn symbolyzed my friend's parents, which were deeply connected with his emotional life. So, what was the interpretation of the whole number? My friend and I came to the final meaning together as we talked about it, like it should always be during the interpretation of the subconscious language. Obviously he didn't like the imposition of his parents. He was a young adult, and he should have been able to control his own finances. At first, he had been angry at his parents for their meddling with his money. But, being a good guy and a loving son, he was slowly coming to the conclusion that his parents, after all, were not asking him anything different from what they themselves had done when they were his age and made sacrifices for a better future. They had to fight for survival, just like the dinosaurs, and his parents' sacrifices had earned him a comfortable life. They didn't deserve his anymosity for just passing down to him their wisdom. The number he had "randomly" chosen just happened to be the perfect expression of his feelings: anger and a sense of guilt for being angry. He was basically bargaining with these two emotions. Needless to say, when my friend thought of the number, he had no idea he was going to express his emotional state through it. He just thought of a random number. That's it. See where all of this leads us? If our minds are incapable of producing a single random thought, even about trivial issues, even about the most emotionally neutral thing you can imagine, like pulling a number out of the air, how can we expect our thoughts not to be determined by our emotions and, most importantly, by our subconscious' need to express them in symbols. When the most trivial idea comes to your mind, seemingly out of nowhere, you may think it's just a casual thought, but the truth is, your subconscious is expressing itself about either some important, emonationally charged issue that runs in the back of your mind, or a biological need, like hunger or thirst, or even sexual desire. The point is, it will probably do it using symbols, because those are the words of its language. Now, where is free will in all of this? Let me tell you plain and simple: there is no such thing as free will. Our life runs on tracks, and there is no way to take a different course from what has been determined before we were even born. We can talk about quantum mechanics all day: how the potential states of reality become substantialized in the actual reality, the one that we perceive day by day, with our very limited senses, but in the end, everything that happens is determined by that which had happened before. And there is no way around it. So what is the meaning of all of this? Is there a meaning at all? I believe so, but this will be material for another discussion.

Nature and nurture (perhaps combined with chance) seem to cover the bases well enough on their own. What you want us to consider, limits your question. That is fine. However, the answer to your question may be outside of the limits that you impose. Your question is about free will. You then ask us to consider the brain and molecules. In Ken Wilber's model, this would be in the individual-exterior domain. Your question cannot be answered within the considerations that you impose. It's like analysing the emotional impact of, for example, Edward Munch's Scream by analysing the chemical composition of the pigments in the paint he used. Ken Wilber is of course not the only philosopher that points out these different approaches. Our western culture and society is dominated by an objective view of the world. It allows us to greatly master the material component of our lives. At the same time, we deny the subjective viewpoint. We try to reduce it to interactions between neurons, but we don't have a solution for the increasing unhappiness in our society. We stuff our kids with pills and when it doesn't really help, we tell ourselves it's a matter of learning more about the chemicals in the brain and creating better medicines. Just like the scientific method allowed us to dominate the objective material world, it can be used to get insights into the subjective, introspective experience. For example, Buddhism has several theories of what you will find when you introspect. You will encounter several experiences and levels of consciousness. Those are just like scientific theories: nobody can prove them, but they can be corroborated. Like with good science, the experiments have been documented. You can reproduce what others have tried before. And you can talk to experts to validate your own experiments. If you try that approach, maybe you can find an answer to your question about free will. I can't tell you the answer. But there have been many others who have executed these experiments and who have documented them. Try looking up those who have experience. I would suggest starting with Zen or yoga. You will find it's easier to discuss free will in that context than in the context of molecular biology.

When contemplating this question, it helps to be aware of three schools of thought: indeterminism, determinism, and compatibilism. The way these concepts respond and conflict with each other give shape to the argument for or against free will. Indeterminism is the belief in autonomous agents - entities that are responsible for their own actions. At least some events in the universe occur randomly. While this does not equate to free will, some philosophers believe it allows for human beings to act from their own agency. Determinism is the notion that all laws of the universe are set. Every action or event that plays out does so because there was no other alternative. You have no choice but to act exactly are you are. Compatibilism is the concept that even if all actions are pre-determined, and an individual has no alternative, as long as the actions they take are motivated by their own character and desire (rather than compulsion), then their free will remains intact. The relevant distinction seems to be that inevitable action is not necessarily compelled action - if it is wanted, it cannot be forced. The argument here is that there is no requirement for genuine alternate possibilities, for free will to exist. Compatibilism seems to consider freedom an emotional experience - so as long as your actions are aligned with your desires - your will is free. There’s no definitive answer, at least that I know of. But these are interesting view points that may help you form your own beliefs!

In what circumstances could free will exist? If I am heading home from work there is only one way I could go which is the most efficient way to satisfy my current objectives which are in general to get home the fastest, cheapest most direct way. There are choices of course, I could take a long way around for a change but only if the desire to do so entered my mind at the time. This would mean a new objective of which I dont have a choice over, rather one that had a prior cause outside of my own direct choice. I could go left instead of right if going right were apparantly more dangerous, but that still satisfies my desire to get home safely. I could defy my objective of being safe by going right despite the danger, but only if a new objective, say to experience a bit of excitement or danger, but that is still a decision based on an objective of outcomes. Free will might give me the choice to go an unusual way but only if there was a reason for it. So free will would only be possible if I were to choose a route that went against any of my desired outcomes. Free will would therefore be a less effective way and wouldnt be a very good idea would it? What use is free will if it can only be applied to defy my desired outcome? Any decision I make must be logical and efficient and must satisfy my objectives. So apart from defying my objectives where does free will play a valuable role? You could argue that free will could be employed ahead of time in choosing which objectives I aim to achieve in general, but again there must be a reason for that also. Can you think of a decision you could make in any aspect of life that doesnt directly take you to your destination without an a priori benefit?

Within a given universe, e.g., ours, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle applies. Therefore, individuals within that universe have free will, since they can choose and you cannot know (or calculate) with certainty what choice they will make (the choice is nondeterministic, because of the HUP). Across all identical universes within the multiverse, there is a calculable PROBABILITY that an individual will chose a particular path. Thus, across all universes, all possible choices will be made, at a statistically determinable frequency. This appears deterministic. However, that only applies (i.e., is deterministic) if a single individual exists across all universes. Since an individual in one universe isn’t aware of his counterpart in another universe, they are separate, although identical entities (at least identical up to the point where they decide differently). Thus, each individual occurrence of the same person however has free will within his universe. The problem has been that we get hung up on the identical person in two or more universes being the SAME person. They are not. Therefore, each is free to choose. Free will exists for individuals in their universe.

I believe that we have no way of knowing, and we never will know, whether humans have Free Will or are governed entirely by Causal Determinism — with every thought being the inexorably determined consequence of prior activity in the universe that predates the dawn of mankind. Causal Determinism is a metaphysical paradigm that posits that all activity in the universe is both (i) the effect of [all] antecedent activity, and (ii) the only activity that can occur given the antecedent activity. That is what is meant by saying that everything is “determined” (or “predetermined” or “destined”) to occur — it is the inexorable consequence of activity that preceded it. In a deterministic universe, everything that has ever occurred, is occurring, and will occur since the universe came into existence (however that might have occurred) can only occur exactly as it has occurred, is occurring, or will occur, and cannot possibly occur in any different manner. Causal Determinism does not address the manner by which activity first began. Nor does Causal Determinism address whether activity is intelligently and intentionally designed, or simply occurs based on a random beginning. As such, a belief in a deterministic universe neither precludes nor requires a belief in God. Moreover, Causal Determinism generally explains the process by which all activity occurs without getting into the details of what specifically causes any particular activity. Causal Determinism posits that everything has a cause and cannot occur in any manner other than how it does occur — without regard to the ability to predict or replicate that activity. Causal Determinism does not posit that the factors that have caused, are causing, or will cause any particular activity can be known or understood, or that any specific future activity can be predicted with any degree of certainty. As Karl Popper has explained: “The metaphysical doctrine of determinism simply asserts that all events in this world are fixed, or unalterable, or predetermined. It does not assert that they are known to anybody, or predictable by scientific means. But it asserts that the future is as little changeable as is the past. Everybody knows what we mean when we say that the past cannot be changed. It is in precisely the same sense that the future cannot be changed, according to metaphysical determinism.” If Causal Determinism is true, then everything and everyone is bound, in lock-step, to a determined and unalterable future — hence, no Free Will. If Causal Determinism is not true, however, it may be that some things (if not everything) is free to evolve in a manner that is not destined, including human will. Unfortunately, Causal Determinism cannot be proved true nor falsified, as explained in Does quantum mechanics undermine hard determinism?; Since "God plays dice" in the quantum sense and the Universe is not deterministic, does this mean we have free will?; and Is it true that everything that happens is predetermined?. Nor can the existence of Free Will be proved or falsified, as explained at Is there really anything as free will? Like the existence (or lack thereof) of [a] “God,” people can only have faith that Free Will exists (or does not exist) and/or that Causal Determinism is true (or false), and should not waste their time searching for proof that does not exist — unless, of course, Causal Determinism is true, Free Will does not exist, and searching for proof is what people are compelled to do by forces beyond their control. ————————————————————————————————————- Causal Determinism – We Are Compelled to Be Free

It depends on what you mean by “free”. If you mean, “can I do something that not even god could predict?” then the answer is no, you don't have free will. If you mean “if all the universe is in a known state and I do something, and then the universe were put back to the same state, will I be able to do something different second time round?” again the answer is no, you don't have free will. If you mean “is there something I can do that will be a surprise to me and everyone else, even someone who knows every thing about me? “ then yes, you do have free will. It is always more complicated than you think.

If the universe is causal, say deterministic, then what happened in the past determines the future. There seems to be no room for free will. But: if the past determines the present, and the present determines the future, then, if we have a choice between A and B in the present, what would happen? Say the history is HA. Say that this history leads to choice A. Say the corresponding future is FA. Then would would happen if we decided to choose B? HA leads to choice A. So if we choose B, HA should be HB, with the corresponding future FB! So if there is free will, the choice you make will affect the future and the past. This affect could just be correlation or dependence in mathematical sense. That way determinism and free will are compatible. I am assuming a deterministic universe and a dualistic mind/matter separation, where the mind or spirit influences the material world, in the brain.

Think about this; does the thing you did and the thing that happened to you most previously influence your next action or does your most previous action have no effect on your future? Is your next decision independent of any outside influence or is your next decision dependent on outside influence? Can any two humans think or act the same way at any point in time? Is procrastination just a natural process which will eventually lead to the one expected outcome, or is it a controlled process which can lead to any outcome? Let’s visualize this. I woke up in the morning and had breakfast, I hate my job and I procrastinated for 15 minutes as to whether or not I wanted to go to work. Eventually during the procrastination, I realize that I need the money and therefore I must go to work. Subsequently I rushed out of the house to ensure that I am not late for work. At the very point in time when I made the conscious decision to go to work, all of the individuals that I will cross path with are in motion. John left his home at a certain time based on the circumstances that he is experiencing; independent of any coordination with me and so did I. Based on the circumstances I am experiencing at that point I walked at a particular pace which allowed me to cross path with John. Based on who John and I am, John sparked a conversation and asked me “how is your morning going?” and I responded. Being both talkers, the enticing conversation influenced us to slow our pace of walking; which lead to both of us being late for work. Could this event had happened any differently? Yes, only if the circumstances we were experiencing were different. One must now ponder if whether or not the circumstances could be different and while searching for that answer, you would realize that it would only be possible under one condition. This means that even circumstances are dependent on circumstances. The work day continued and based on the conditions and how my boss is, he approached me and asked “why are you late today?” I responded and while responding a co-worker was passing by and heard me. Moments before this event, some water spilled on the floor and while my co-worker was passing by inquisitively, this caused her to slip and fall. Being who I am, I rushed to her aid and the discussion with my boss ended. This event became the centre of discussion for most of the day for just about everyone. Everything I did that day was dependent on two things the circumstances that exist at each point in time and who I am. If you happen to travel to the woods and eventually got bitten by a snake, was this a coincidence? Or was this because the circumstances that both you and the snake were experiencing lead you both in the same direction which ultimately lead to both paths intersecting and based on the nature of the snake, it had no choice but to bite you? If you happen to be going on your way to the grocery store as a result of your circumstances and ultimately cross path with someone who previously broke into your house and you eventually hit them, was this a coincidence or was this because the circumstances that both you and the person were experiencing lead you both in the same direction which ultimately lead to both paths intersecting and based on your nature, you had no choice but to hit the person? One will argue that I the individual is both the origin and cause of my actions but this logic cannot be further from the truth. Every action has a motive, if I say I need a Job, this must be for a reason which originated outside of myself and it is this reason; circumstance which caused my action not me. One will also say that if I wake up one morning and say that I desire a house, then I must be the origin of the action to come. This is true, but even desire itself is caused by circumstances. In Genesis, Eve didn’t desire the fruit in the garden until the serpent enticed her and being how she is, she decided to eat of the forbidden fruit. Even though it-self is dependent on circumstances. One’s ability to think is dependent on the extent of their knowledge and understanding, which is dependent on their exposure which is determined by the conditions that exist throughout their life. By now you should realize the premise of these situations and by extension all situations. Everything that you or anyone experience is caused by circumstances. The effect of each circumstance is based on who you are.

This is my official response to the free will debate: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ I have no idea if free will is a meaningful concept in the first place, so the question of whether we have it often seems somewhat pointless to me. It depends on your definition of free will. It isn’t obvious, and there are several definitions which contradict each other. The most common definition among philosophers and laypeople is compatibilism: you act freely if you do so without coercion. Compatibilist free will is, as the name suggests, compatible with determinism. This sort of free will obviously exists, and it is important that it exists. But some people, incompatibilists, don’t think it should be called “free will”. Incompatibilism is the position you are assuming in the question. The main problem with this is that it would not be possible to function if your actions were not caused by antecedents (which includes all internal and external factors). Normally, your actions are determined by your preferences, values, fears, anticipated consequences and so on. Think about what would happen if your actions were NOT so determined, or were only partly determined. It might not mattter if you were choosing a flavour of ice cream, but it would be a disaster if you were doing something as simple as crossing the road, or trying to feed yourself. Fortunately, we don’t have this type of free will.

response.answer_text: Ultimately, I don’t think it is possible to be sure if there is free will or not. There are decent arguments for both sides, but of course we would hope that free will exists and few people adequately account for the bias this imposes. Free will may be something akin to a drop of water running along ones windshield. There is a trail of water from previous drops. New Drops would tend along this line. However, they often pop off to one side or the other for no apparent reason. The drop appears to do something that obvious physics would suggest it wouldn’t. The drop is obviously not choosing to take a different route. it is acting on the complete sum of the physics, even though it appears not to be. Humans may well not have free will, it may well be simply we have the appearance and thus the belief of free will due to holes in our understanding of EVERY action that affects our ‘decisions.’ However, this matters little insofar as we must make decisions (not to decide is a decision) regardless. Perhaps these decisions are made based on something that happened when we were young, or because we read a book, or because an enormous chain of events that caused our brain chemistry to be a certain way, and also caused those things that happened when we were young.

Does free will exist? In the context of our limited human perspective, yes. That is to say, even if our lives are destined to play out in a certain way, every single decision we make is based on inherently incomplete and inaccurate knowledge. If we choose to abdicate our responsibility for making those decisions, that is also a choice. As for whether we can actually make meaningful choices, the jury's still out. Most existentialists would say yes; most determinists would say no. (See Does determinism undermine existentialism? ) But we really don't know for certain whether the laws of physics are immutable, or whether God plays dice with the universe. (See Does God Play Dice? )

No, it seems not. Brains are the human organs responsible for decision-making. Brains - being physical - operate according to the strict and immutable laws of physics. As such, with every input, there is - and can only be - a singular output. Therefore, we do not get the freedom of “choice” as we believe we do. You can plead the existence of a “soul”, but even if we assume its existence you have to explain why decisions seem to be made by the brain, and how the soul is supposed to have any meaningful sense of control over the strictly-physical body (which also adheres to the immutable laws of physics). There’s no room for free will, either way. It cannot logically exist.

It's certainly possible to define a continuum of events running from those caused entirely by events outside your brain to those caused entirely (or nearly so) by events inside your brain. At one end, for instance, there would be the brief descent to the ground after falling over a cliff, which you have no internal input into at all. At the other end, perhaps, choosing to daydream about film star A rather than film star B. And when the term 'free will' is used intelligibly, it denotes events at the 'internal' end of the scale, where most of the direct causal input takes place within the confines of your skull. If it's used in any other way... good luck trying to make sense of it.

Depends on how you define free will. =] But seriously, that's the crux of the question over the past 100 years or so. If you define free will in the naive sense, where it's some magical force from outside the universe coming in and causing changes in the physical world that can't be explained by physics, then, at least if you have a generally scientific/physicalist worldview, it clearly doesn't exist. Everything people do is consistent with the laws of physics, so if free will exists, it must be something that happens within physics, not outside of it. The question is what exactly that means, or if it makes sense to call it "free will". Much, much more here: http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/freewill/ More on the specific take I highlight (free will within a universe ruled by physical causality) here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compatibilism_and_incompatibilism

At the quantum level the universe is decidedly not deterministic, but it's also not entirely random, there are constraints. Random with constraints allows for probabilities to be given but still not be able to predict anything with absolute certainty. At the macroscopic level the universe DOES tend to be deterministic, but there are still some isolated situations where quantum effects can be observed at the macroscopic level (like the Bose-Einstein condensate superfluid helium-4). It's also possible (though extremely difficult and uncommon) for macroscopic stuff to have an impact on the outcome of quantum effects. Therefore it's possible, though fairly unlikely, that our macroscopic brains can both influence and be influenced by quantum (and therefore random-with-constraints) events. This idea is a purely philosophical one, and is pretty much entirely pseudoscience (at least until someone comes up with a way to test it), but it's how I am able, at least for the moment, to hold onto the possibility of free will.

I do not believe in non-causal choice, but I believe in free will. Let me explain. First, we must define free will. If one has the power to make a *choice* that is determined by an unpredictable process, I would consider that a good enough practical definition of 'free will'. In this sense, I'd argue that free will exists. Imagine there is a true random number generator (RNG) that returns a 1 or 0, with 1 being take the red pill and 0 being take the blue pill, and I choose to take whichever pill is decided by the RNG. Then my choice is entirely explained by the result of the RNG, and thus my choice would be random and unpredictable. My impulses and desires might compel me to reach for the blue pill, but if the RNG returned a 1, I would exercise free will by choosing the red pill. My action would express my will to be free from all that happened before the result of the RNG. If this is not free will, I don't know what is.

It’s a question of logic and philosophical attitude rather than science. A compatibilist will say that even if the universe is for all intents and purposes deterministic, that fact that we feel free in our choices is what matters. A hard determinist will probably demur, saying that what is true is what matters, and so if the universe is deterministic, for all intents and purposes, then free choice is an illusion and we are merely acting out the messy but deterministic pathways of biology. Being a programmer by background, I tend to go more with the latter rather than the former and say what we have is probably the best possible scenario, in which we feel free within a safe and structured context, whereas total and real freedom on the other hand, were it possible, would be meaningless chaos - choices that were truly free of any determining factor would be just random events.

You have asked one of the most important and profound of all philosophical questions. The short answer is, no one really knows. On one hand, it’s very difficult to understand how free will could be even possible. On the other, giving up belief in free will would arguably require that we abandon some of our most important beliefs about who we are—including whether anyone is ever responsible for their actions. Due to the complexity and difficulty of the topic, I recommend treating anyone who thinks they really know the answer with extreme skepticism. I won’t go any deeper or I’d be writing all day, but the following article is a good intro to the topic. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/freewill/

This phrasing of the question seeks to salvage "free will" by arguing that the universe is not strictly deterministic from a physics perspective. However, determinism at the universal level is not required to bury "free will". We already know that our biology [including our brains] operate at a deterministic level.  While this may not be 100%, it is sufficiently deterministic that allows us to live, survive, and predict with relative certainty how we need to respond to various situations. However, the irony occurs because "free will" requires absolute determinism.  It postulates that an individual can act specifically and intentionally to produce an outcome.  It doesn't get any more deterministic than that. So, determinism clearly indicates that "free will" cannot exist.  It cannot be salvaged by invoking the randomness of quantum physics, since "free will" itself must be deterministic in order to produce the desired result. "Free will" cannot exist.

What we think and do at any moment in time is the inevitable consequence of a very complicated web of interdependent causes. Both inevitable and unpredictable. Which does not mean we cannot learn. The content of our brain can change as a consequence of the same complicated web of interdependent causes.

This is analogous to how you can only see what your eyes are directed at right now, but that doesn’t mean that what’s behind you doesn’t exist, even if you’ve never seen it. How does this relate to free will? Well, objectively speaking, the future is predetermined, but with infinite alternative scenarios, each of which has the potential to be experienced by you. The assertion that “free will doesn’t exist” denotes the idea that it is not possible for an agent to freely choose the outcomes of his deliberations. Instead the outcome is either pre-determined (deterministic view) or results from indeterministic factors that are outside of the agent’s control (indeterministic view; think quantum physics). Just to be clear, nothing said above prevents the experience/illusion of a free will by the agent. Nor does the ontological absence of free will - should you accept this assertion - has much effect on how we live our lives. As agents, we cannot lean back so to speak, and be an observer to our unfree actions. Whether we have free will or not, our deliberations cannot feel otherwise than an exercise of free will (even though this feeling is illusionary). Futhermore, given the complex processes that underlie our thinking and deliberations, and given the almost infinite variables that determine the outcome of these deliberations, we will never be able to predict them. The only practical consequence of accepting the non-existence of free will is that we should no longer accept revenge as a factor in punishing people who commit a crime. Deterrence would still be a valid argument, as would extracting a harmful indvidual from public life, but adding revenge-induced articles to a punishment would no longer make sense. Hope this helps

We should also be able to predict when he or she will do the complete opposite of what we predict because that too would be the result of predictable interactions. Unless the person knew we were on to them. Which would also be something we could predict, thereby making their predictable unpredictable predictability something we could also predict. Unless they were also on to that. And if … You see how quickly this collapses into an endless chain of predictability and unpredictability. We can’t be sure if we have free will or not because we will never have access to enough information since there is an infinite regression of causes. So we might as well act as though we have the free will we appear to have.
